1002.a.Problem Statement:
A beam of electrons with kinetic energy $1 \mathrm{keV}$ is diffracted as it passes through a polycrystalline metal foil. The metal has a cubic crystal structure with a spacing of $1 \AA$. Given $m, q, h, c$,

calculate the wavelength of the electrons,
1002.a.Solution:
The electron wavelength is

$$
\lambda=\frac{h}{p}
$$

with $p$ given by 

$$
\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}=e V,
$$

$V$ being the accelerating voltage of the electrons. Thus

$$
\lambda=\frac{h}{(2 m e V)^{1 / 2}} \approx \frac{12.25}{V^{1 / 2}}=\frac{12.25}{\sqrt{1000}}=0.39 \AA .
$$
1002.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

1002.b.Problem Statement:
A beam of electrons with kinetic energy $1 \mathrm{keV}$ is diffracted as it passes through a polycrystalline metal foil. The metal has a cubic crystal structure with a spacing of $1 \AA$. Given $m, q, h, c$,

calculate the Bragg angle for the first order diffraction maximum.
1002.b.Solution:
The electron wavelength is

$$
\lambda=\frac{h}{p}
$$

with $p$ given by 

$$
\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}=e V,
$$

$V$ being the accelerating voltage of the electrons. Thus

$$
\lambda=\frac{h}{(2 m e V)^{1 / 2}} \approx \frac{12.25}{V^{1 / 2}}=\frac{12.25}{\sqrt{1000}}=0.39 \AA .
$$The condition for Bragg reflection

$$
2 d \sin \theta=n \lambda
$$

gives for the first order diffraction maximum

$$
\sin \theta=\frac{\lambda}{2 d}=\frac{0.39}{2 \times 1}=0.195
$$

as $n=1, d=1 \AA$. Hence

$$
\theta=11.18^{\circ} \text {. }
$$

1003.b.Problem Statement:
While sitting in front of a color TV with a $25 \mathrm{kV}$ picture tube potential, you have an excellent chance of being irradiated with $\mathrm{X}$-rays.

For the resulting continuous distribution, calculate the shortest wavelength (maximum energy) X-ray.
( $h=6.6 \times 10^{-34} \mathrm{Js}, c=3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, $\left.1 \mathrm{eV}=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{~J}\right)$
1003.b.Solution:
When a high voltage is applied to the picture tube, electrons emitted from the negative electrode will be accelerated by the electric field to strike the screen target. If the energy of the electrons exceeds a certain value, they can knock off inner-shell electrons in the target atoms and make holes in the inner shells. Then as the outer-shell electrons fall in to fill up these holes, X-rays are emitted.
The maximum energy of the X-ray photons produced, $h \nu_{\max }$, is equal to the energy $\mathrm{eV}$ of the incident electrons. Hence the minimum wavelength of the X-rays is

$$
\lambda_{\min }=\frac{h c}{e V}=\frac{12000}{V}=\frac{12000}{25 \times 10^{3}}=0.48 \AA .
$$
1003.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

1003.c.Problem Statement:
While sitting in front of a color TV with a $25 \mathrm{kV}$ picture tube potential, you have an excellent chance of being irradiated with $\mathrm{X}$-rays.

For a rock salt $(\mathrm{NaCl})$ crystal placed in front of the tube, calculate the Bragg angle for a first order reflection maximum at $\lambda=0.5 \AA$. $\left(\rho_{\mathrm{NaCl}}=\right.$ $\left.2.165 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}\right)$
1003.c.Solution:
When a high voltage is applied to the picture tube, electrons emitted from the negative electrode will be accelerated by the electric field to strike the screen target. If the energy of the electrons exceeds a certain value, they can knock off inner-shell electrons in the target atoms and make holes in the inner shells. Then as the outer-shell electrons fall in to fill up these holes, X-rays are emitted.
The maximum energy of the X-ray photons produced, $h \nu_{\max }$, is equal to the energy $\mathrm{eV}$ of the incident electrons. Hence the minimum wavelength of the X-rays is

$$
\lambda_{\min }=\frac{h c}{e V}=\frac{12000}{V}=\frac{12000}{25 \times 10^{3}}=0.48 \AA .
$$Bragg's law

$$
2 d \sin \theta=n \lambda
$$

gives the angle $\theta$ for the first order diffraction $(n=1)$ maximum:

$$
\sin \theta=\frac{\lambda}{2 d},
$$

where $d$ is the distance between two neighboring ions in the $\mathrm{NaCl}$ crystal.

As $\mathrm{NaCl}$ crystal has a simple cubic structure with $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$and $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$ions arranged alternately, there are $N_{0} \mathrm{Na}^{+}$ions and $N_{0} \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$ions in a mole of $\mathrm{NaCl}$, where $N_{0}$ is Avogadro's number. As $\mathrm{NaCl}$ has a molar weight $M=58.45 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{mol}$ and a density $\rho=2.165 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}$, its crystal has

$$
d=\left(\frac{\frac{M}{\rho}}{2 N_{0}}\right)^{1 / 3}=\left(\frac{\frac{58.45}{2.165 \times 10^{6}}}{2 \times 6.02 \times 10^{23}}\right)^{1 / 3}=2.82 \AA .
$$

This gives

$$
\sin \theta=\frac{0.5}{2 \times 2.82}=0.088
$$

and hence

$$
\theta=5^{\circ} \text {. }
$$
1003.c.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

1005.a.Problem Statement:
$\mathrm{NaCl}$ crystallizes in a face-centered cubic lattice with a basis of $\mathrm{Na}$ and $\mathrm{Cl}$ ions separated by half the body diagonal of the cube. The atomic numbers of $\mathrm{Na}$ and $\mathrm{Cl}$ are 11 and 17 respectively.

Determine which X-ray reflections will be observed (indexed for the conventional cubic unit cell).
1005.a.Solution:
The unit cell of $\mathrm{NaCl}$ includes eight atoms occupying the following positions: $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$at $\left(\begin{array}{lll}0 & 0 & 0\end{array}\right),\left(\frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{2} 0\right),\left(\frac{1}{2} 0 \frac{1}{2}\right),\left(0 \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{2}\right)$, as indicated by solid circles in Fig. 1.4; $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$at $\left(\frac{1}{2} 00\right),\left(0 \frac{1}{2} 0\right),\left(00 \frac{1}{2}\right),\left(\frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{2}\right)$, as indicated by open circles in the figures.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_b8e2b1af07958c90efe7g-17.jpg?height=675&width=824&top_left_y=1722&top_left_x=648)

Fig. $1.4$ The diffraction intensities are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{h k l} & \propto\left|F_{h k l}\right|^{2}=F_{h k l} \cdot F_{h k l}^{*} \\
&=\left[\sum_{j} f_{j} \cos 2 \pi\left(h u_{j}+k v_{j}+l w_{j}\right)\right]^{2} \\
&+\left[\sum_{j} f_{j} \sin 2 \pi\left(h u_{j}+k v_{j}+l w_{j}\right)\right]^{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $h, k, l$ are integers. Substitution of the ions' coordinates leads to

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{h k l}=& f_{\mathrm{Na}^{+}}^{2}\{[1+\cos \pi(h+k)+\cos \pi(k+l)+\cos \pi(l+h)]\\
&+\alpha[\cos \pi h+\cos \pi k+\cos \pi l+\cos \pi(h+k+l)]\}^{2} \\
&+f_{\mathrm{Na}}^{2}\{[\sin \pi(h+k)+\sin \pi(k+l)+\sin \pi(l+h)]\\
&+\alpha[\sin \pi h+\sin \pi k+\sin \pi l+\sin \pi(h+k+l)]\}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\alpha=f_{\mathrm{Cl}^{-}} / f_{\mathrm{Na}^{+}}=17 / 11$.

It is noted that the intensities $I_{h k l} \neq 0$ only when $h, k$ and $l$ are all odd numbers or all even numbers. Thus two different groups of diffracted beams can be observed.

1007.Problem Statement: Diffraction studies involving X-rays, electrons or neutrons give information about the crystallographic properties of solids. Compare these three techniques with reference to particle energies and types of information that can be obtained. Which technique is most appropriate for studying surface crystallography? Which technique is used to determine magnetic structure?
1007.Solution:
The typical energy of $\mathrm{X}$-rays is several thousand $\mathrm{eV}$, corresponding to a wavelength of about $10^{-10} \mathrm{~m}$, which is of the same order of magnitude as the interplanar distance in a crystal. Hence X-rays are suitable for determining crystal lattice structures. For low energy diffraction studies, energies $20-50 \mathrm{eV}$ are usually employed. Because of the large cross section of crystal atoms for scattering of low energy electrons, the incident electrons cannot penetrate deeply into a crystal. Thus low energy electron diffraction is an important technique for studying the surface structures of solids. A neutron sees two aspects of a crystal: distribution of nuclei and distribution of electronic magnetization. Hence the diffraction of neutrons by a magnetic crystal allows the determination of the distribution, orientation and order of the magnetic moments.

In brief, low energy electron diffraction is most suitable for studying surface crystallography, and neutron diffraction for determining magnetic structures of crystals.
1007.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

1008.Problem Statement: X-rays are reflected from a crystal by Bragg reflection. If the density of the crystal which is of an accurately known structure is measured with an rms error of 3 parts in $10^{4}$, and if the angle the incident and reflected rays make with the crystal plane is $6^{\circ}$ and is measured with an rms error of $3.4$ minutes of arc, then what is the rms error in the determination of the X-ray wavelength?
1008.Solution:
For simplicity consider a crystal whose primitive cell is simple cubic with edge $d$ (to be multiplied by a factor of about one for the primitive cells of other crystal structures). For first order reflection, $n=1$ and Bragg's law gives

$$
2 d \sin \theta=\lambda .
$$

Differentiating, we have

$$
\left|\frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda}\right|=\left|\frac{\Delta d}{d}\right|+\cot \theta|\Delta \theta| .
$$

The volume of a unit cell is

$$
d^{3}=\frac{M}{\rho N_{0}},
$$

where $M$ is the molar weight and $\rho$ the mass density of the crystal, and $N_{0}$ is Avogadro's number. This differentiates to give 

$$
\left|\frac{\Delta d}{d}\right|=\frac{1}{3}\left|\frac{\Delta \rho}{\rho}\right| .
$$

Thus

$$
\left|\frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda}\right|=\frac{1}{3}\left|\frac{\Delta \rho}{\rho}\right|+\cot \theta \cdot|\Delta \theta|,
$$

and, in terms of rms errors,

$$
\frac{\sigma_{\lambda}}{\lambda}=\left[\left(\frac{1}{3} \frac{\sigma_{\rho}}{\rho}\right)^{2}+\left(\sigma_{\theta} \cot \theta\right)^{2}\right]^{1 / 2} \text {. }
$$

As $\frac{\sigma_{\rho}}{\rho}=3 \times 10^{-4}, \sigma_{\theta} \cot \theta=\frac{\sigma_{\theta} \cos \theta}{\sin \theta} \approx \frac{\sigma_{\theta}}{\theta}=\frac{3.4}{60 \times 6}=9.4 \times 10^{-3}$,

$$
\frac{\sigma_{\lambda}}{\lambda}=\sqrt{10^{-8}+\left(9.4 \times 10^{-3}\right)^{2}}=9.4 \times 10^{-3} .
$$
1008.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

1010.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a line of $2 N$ ions of alternating charges $\pm q$ with a repulsive potential $A / R^{n}$ between nearest neighbors in addition to the usual Coulomb potential.

Find the equilibrium separation $R_{0}$ for such a system and evaluate the equilibrium energy $U\left(R_{0}\right)$.
1010.a.Solution:
Neglecting surface effects, the lattice energy of the system is

$$
U(R)=N\left(-\frac{a q^{2}}{R}+\frac{A}{R^{n}}\right),
$$

where $a$ is the Madelung constant. $U(R)$ is a minimum at equilibrium. So the equilibrium separation $R_{0}$ is given by

$$
\left(\frac{d U}{d R}\right)_{R=R_{0}}=0,
$$

whence the equilibrium separation

$$
R_{0}=\left(\frac{n A}{a q^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{n-1}}
$$

and hence the equilibrium energy

$$
\begin{aligned}
U\left(R_{0}\right) &=-\frac{N}{R_{0}}\left(a q^{2}-\frac{A}{R_{0}^{n-1}}\right) \\
&=-\frac{N a q^{2}}{R_{0}}\left(1-\frac{1}{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

with $a=2 \ln 2$ for a one-dimensional chain.
1010.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

1010.b.Problem Statement:
Consider a line of $2 N$ ions of alternating charges $\pm q$ with a repulsive potential $A / R^{n}$ between nearest neighbors in addition to the usual Coulomb potential.

Let the crystal be compressed so that $R_{0} \rightarrow R_{0}(1-\delta)$. Calculate the work done in compressing a unit length of the crystal to order $\delta^{2}$.
1010.b.Solution:
Neglecting surface effects, the lattice energy of the system is

$$
U(R)=N\left(-\frac{a q^{2}}{R}+\frac{A}{R^{n}}\right),
$$

where $a$ is the Madelung constant. $U(R)$ is a minimum at equilibrium. So the equilibrium separation $R_{0}$ is given by

$$
\left(\frac{d U}{d R}\right)_{R=R_{0}}=0,
$$

whence the equilibrium separation

$$
R_{0}=\left(\frac{n A}{a q^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{n-1}}
$$

and hence the equilibrium energy

$$
\begin{aligned}
U\left(R_{0}\right) &=-\frac{N}{R_{0}}\left(a q^{2}-\frac{A}{R_{0}^{n-1}}\right) \\
&=-\frac{N a q^{2}}{R_{0}}\left(1-\frac{1}{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

with $a=2 \ln 2$ for a one-dimensional chain.When the crystal is compressed so that $R_{0}$ becomes $R$, the increase in the lattice energy is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
U(R)-U\left(R_{0}\right) &=N\left[-a q^{2}\left(\frac{1}{R}-\frac{1}{R_{0}}\right)+A\left(\frac{1}{R^{2}}-\frac{1}{R_{0}^{n}}\right)\right] \\
&=-\frac{N a q^{2}}{R_{0}}\left[\frac{R_{0}}{R}-1-\frac{1}{n}\left(\frac{R_{0}^{n}}{R^{n}}-1\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

and is equal to the work done $W$ by the applied forces.

As $R=R_{0}(1-\delta)$, retaining terms up to $\delta^{2}$ we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{R_{0}}{R}-1=(1-\delta)^{-1}-1 \approx \delta+\delta^{2}, \\
\left(\frac{R_{0}}{R}\right)^{n}-1=(1-\delta)^{-n}-1 \approx n \delta+\frac{n(n+1)}{2} \delta^{2},
\end{gathered}
$$

and thus

$$
W \approx-\frac{N a q^{2}}{R_{0}}\left(1-\frac{n+1}{2}\right) \delta^{2}=\frac{N a q^{2}}{2 R_{0}}(n-1) \delta^{2} .
$$

The total length of the crystal is approximately $2 N R_{0}$. Hence the work done in compressing a unit length of the crystal is

$$
\frac{W}{2 N R_{0}}=\frac{q^{2}}{R_{0}^{2}} \frac{\ln 2}{2}(n-1) \delta^{2} .
$$
1010.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

1011.a.Problem Statement: What is the cohesive energy with respect to separated ions for crystalline $\mathrm{NaCl}$ ? Give the approximate value and a derivation using a very simple model. Lattice constant $a=5.6 \AA$.
1011.a.Solution:
For a crystal consisting of $N$ ions, each of charge $\pm e$, the cohesive energy is

$$
U(r)=-\frac{N}{2} \sum_{j}^{\prime}\left[\pm \frac{e^{2}}{r_{l j}}-\frac{b}{r_{l j}^{n}}\right]
$$

where $b$ is the Madelung constant and the prime indicates that $j=l$ is excluded from the summation. With $r_{l j}=\alpha_{j} R$ the above becomes

$$
U(R)=-\frac{N}{2}\left(\frac{\alpha e^{2}}{R}-\frac{\beta}{R^{n}}\right),
$$

where

$$
\alpha=\sum_{j}^{\prime}(\pm) \alpha_{j}^{-1}, \quad B=b \sum_{j}^{\prime} \alpha_{j}^{-n}
$$

At equilibrium $U(R)$ is a minimum and $R=R_{0}$ is given by

$$
\left(\frac{\partial U}{\partial R}\right)_{R=R_{0}}=0
$$

which yields

$$
R_{0}=\left(\frac{\alpha e^{2}}{n B}\right)^{\frac{1}{n-1}} .
$$

and thus

$$
U\left(R_{0}\right)=-\frac{N \alpha e^{2}}{2 R_{0}}\left(1-\frac{1}{n}\right) .
$$

The two terms in $U(R)$ are a Coulomb potential and a repulsive potential. By comparing the calculated Coulomb potential and the observed total binding energy, $n$ can be estimated to be about 10 . So to a $10 \%$ accuracy we have

$$
U\left(R_{0}\right) \approx-\frac{N \alpha e^{2}}{2 R_{0}} .
$$

Applying Ewald's method to the known $\mathrm{NaCl}$ structure, we can calculate $\alpha$ and obtain $\alpha=1.7476$. Then with $R_{0}=\frac{a}{2}=2.8 \AA$, we find

$$
U\left(R_{0}\right)=178 \mathrm{kcal} / \mathrm{mol},
$$

as for crystalline $\mathrm{NaCl}, n=8$.
1011.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

1012.a.Problem Statement:
An ideal two-dimensional crystal consists of only one kind of atom (of mass $m$ ), and each atom has an equilibrium location at a point of a square lattice $\mathbf{R}=(r a, s a)$, where $r, s=1,2, \ldots, N$. The displacements from equilibrium are denoted by $\left(x_{r s}, y_{r s}\right)$, i.e.,

$$
\mathbf{R}_{r a}=\left(r a+x_{r s}, s a+y_{r s}\right),
$$

and in the harmonic approximation the potential is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
V\left(x_{r s}, y_{r s}\right)=& \sum_{r, s}\left\{k_{1}\left[\left(x_{(r+1) s}-x_{r s}\right)^{2}\left(y_{r(s+1)}-y_{r s}\right)^{2}\right]\right.\\
&\left.+k_{2}\left[\left(x_{r(s+1)}-x_{r s}\right)^{2}\left(y_{(r+1) s}-y_{r s}\right)^{2}\right]\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

For the case $k_{2}=0.1 k_{1}$,

determine the general phonon dispersion relation $\omega_{q \lambda}$ throughout the Brillouin zone,
1012.a.Solution:
The vibration of an atom at $\mathbf{R}_{r s}=(r a, s a)$ is given by Newton's second law

$$
m \ddot{\mathbf{R}}_{r s}=-\nabla_{r s} V,
$$

where

$$
\nabla_{r s} \equiv \mathbf{e}_{x} \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{r s}}+\mathbf{e}_{y} \frac{\partial}{\partial y_{r s}} .
$$

Consider a solution representing a wave traveling in the crystal:

$$
\mathbf{R}_{r s}=\mathbf{A} e^{i(\mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{R}-\omega t)},
$$

where $\mathbf{A}$ is a constant vector. As $\ddot{\mathbf{R}}_{r s}=-\omega^{2} \mathbf{R}_{r s}$ and $x_{r s}$ appears in the sum for $V$ only in the terms

$$
\begin{aligned}
&k_{1}\left[\left(x_{(r+1) s}-x_{r s}\right)^{2}+\left(x_{r s}-x_{(r-1) s}\right)^{2}\right], \\
&k_{2}\left[\left(x_{r(s+1)}-x_{r s}\right)^{2}+\left(x_{r s}-x_{r(s-1)}\right)^{2}\right],
\end{aligned}
$$

substitution of $\mathbf{R}_{r s}$ in the equation of motion gives

$$
-m \omega^{2} x_{r s}=2 k_{1}\left(x_{(r+1) s}+x_{(r-1) s}-2 x_{r s}\right)+2 k_{2}\left(x_{r(s+1)}+x_{r(s-1)}-2 x_{r s}\right)
$$

and, similarly,

$$
-m \omega^{2} y_{r s}=2 k_{1}\left(y_{r(s+1)}+y_{r(s-1)}-2 y_{r s}\right)+2 k_{2}\left(y_{(r+1) s}+y_{(r-1) s}-2 y_{r s}\right) .
$$

With $\mathbf{q}=\left(q_{x}, q_{y}\right), \mathbf{R}=(r a, s a)$, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
x_{r s}=A_{x} e^{i\left[\left(q_{x} r+q_{y} s\right) a-\omega t\right]}, \\
y_{r s}=A_{y} e^{i\left[\left(q_{x} r+q_{y} s\right) a-\omega t\right]} .
\end{gathered}
$$

Substitution gives

$$
-m \omega^{2} x_{r s}=2 k_{1}\left(e^{i q_{x} a}+e^{-i q_{x} a}-2\right) x_{r s}+2 k_{2}\left(e^{i q_{y} a}+e^{-i q_{y} a}-2\right) x_{r s},
$$

or

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega^{2} &=\frac{4 k_{1}}{m}\left[1-\cos \left(q_{x} a\right)\right]+\frac{4 k_{2}}{m}\left[1-\cos \left(q_{y} a\right)\right] \\
&=\omega_{0}^{2}\left[\sin ^{2}\left(\frac{q_{x} a}{2}\right)+\left(\frac{k_{2}}{k_{1}}\right) \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{q_{y} a}{2}\right)\right],
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\omega_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{8 k_{1}}{m}}$. Actually $q_{x}, q_{y}$ in the solution $x_{r s}, y_{r s}$ can be interchanged. Hence there are two phono dispersion relations for $k_{2}=0.1 k_{1}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\omega_{q_{1}}=\omega_{0}\left[\sin ^{2}\left(\frac{q_{x} a}{2}\right)+0.1 \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{q_{y} a}{2}\right)\right]^{1 / 2} \\
&\omega_{q_{2}}=\omega_{0}\left[\sin ^{2}\left(\frac{q_{y} a}{2}\right)+0.1 \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{q_{x} a}{2}\right)\right]^{1 / 2} .
\end{aligned}
$$
1012.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

1013.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a two-dimensional square array of atoms with lattice constant a. The atoms interact so that when the atom at $\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$ is displaced to $\left(x_{0}+\Delta x, y_{0}\right)$, it is subject to a restoring force $-c_{1} \Delta x$ due to its two nearest neighbors at $\left(x_{0} \pm a, y_{0}\right)$ and a restoring force $-c_{2} \Delta x$ due to its two nearest neighbors at $\left(x_{0}, y_{0} \pm a\right)$. Assume $c_{2}<c_{1}$.

Find the dispersion relation for sound waves propagating in the $x$ direction, and draw the dispersion diagram.
1013.a.Solution:
Take the origin at $\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$, then $\left(x_{n}, y_{m}\right)=(n a, m a)$. Let the $x$ displacement of the atom at $\left(x_{n}, y_{m}\right)$ be $u_{n, m}$. The atom's $x$ displacement relative to the nearest neighbors situated parallel to the $x$-axis is

$$
-\left(u_{n+1, m}-u_{n, m}\right)+\left(u_{n, m}-u_{n-1, m}\right)=2 u_{n, m}-u_{n+1, m}-u_{n-1, m},
$$

and that relative to the nearest neighbors situated parallel to the $y$-axis is

$$
2 u_{n, m}-u_{n, m+1}-u_{n, m-1} .
$$

Hence the equation of motion of the atom at $\left(x_{n}, y_{m}\right)$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \frac{d^{2} u_{n, m}}{d t^{2}}=&-C_{1}\left(2 u_{m, n}-u_{n+1, m}-u_{n+1, m}\right) \\
&-C_{2}\left(2 u_{m, n}-u_{n, m+1}-u_{n, m-1}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Try a solution of the form

$$
u_{n, m}=A e^{i\left(q_{1} n a+q_{2} m a-\omega t\right)} .
$$

Substitution gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \omega^{2} &=C_{1}\left(2-e^{i q_{1} a}-e^{-i q_{1} a}\right)+C_{2}\left(2-e^{i q_{2} a}-e^{-i q_{2} a}\right) \\
&=2 C_{1}\left[1-\cos \left(q_{1} a\right)\right]+2 C_{2}\left[1-\cos \left(q_{2} a\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
\omega=\left\{\frac{4 C_{1}}{m} \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{q_{1} a}{2}\right)+\frac{4 C_{2}}{m} \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{q_{2} a}{2}\right)\right\}^{1 / 2} .
$$

For sound waves propagating in the $x$ direction, $q_{2}=0$ and the dispersion relation is as plotted in Fig. 1.6, where $\omega_{m}=\sqrt{\frac{4 C_{1}}{m}}$.
1013.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

1013.b.Problem Statement:
Consider a two-dimensional square array of atoms with lattice constant a. The atoms interact so that when the atom at $\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$ is displaced to $\left(x_{0}+\Delta x, y_{0}\right)$, it is subject to a restoring force $-c_{1} \Delta x$ due to its two nearest neighbors at $\left(x_{0} \pm a, y_{0}\right)$ and a restoring force $-c_{2} \Delta x$ due to its two nearest neighbors at $\left(x_{0}, y_{0} \pm a\right)$. Assume $c_{2}<c_{1}$.

What is the speed of sound in this two-dimensional crystal?

If a few atoms in the lattice are removed from their sites, creating vacancies, the average restoring force for a plane wave of sound is reduced by an amount proportional to the concentration of vacancies. Furthermore, each vacancy will scatter any incident sound wave, and the amplitude of the scattered wave is $A / \lambda$ for $\lambda \gg a$, where $\lambda$ is the wavelength and $A$ is a constant.
1013.b.Solution:
Take the origin at $\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$, then $\left(x_{n}, y_{m}\right)=(n a, m a)$. Let the $x$ displacement of the atom at $\left(x_{n}, y_{m}\right)$ be $u_{n, m}$. The atom's $x$ displacement relative to the nearest neighbors situated parallel to the $x$-axis is

$$
-\left(u_{n+1, m}-u_{n, m}\right)+\left(u_{n, m}-u_{n-1, m}\right)=2 u_{n, m}-u_{n+1, m}-u_{n-1, m},
$$

and that relative to the nearest neighbors situated parallel to the $y$-axis is

$$
2 u_{n, m}-u_{n, m+1}-u_{n, m-1} .
$$

Hence the equation of motion of the atom at $\left(x_{n}, y_{m}\right)$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \frac{d^{2} u_{n, m}}{d t^{2}}=&-C_{1}\left(2 u_{m, n}-u_{n+1, m}-u_{n+1, m}\right) \\

1014.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a $d$-dimensional vibrating lattice at zero temperature. The number density is $\eta$ and the atoms have mass $m$. Using the Debye approximation and assuming all sound modes to have the same velocity $v$
Evaluate the mean square displacement $\left\langle R^{2}\right\rangle$ for $d=3$.
1014.a.Solution:
$d=3$. In the Debye approximation, the number of modes of oscillation with wave numbers less than $q$ is given by the volume, measured in units of $\left(\frac{2 \pi}{L}\right)^{3}, L$ being the length of the lattice, assumed cubic, of a sphere of radius $q$ with center at the origin of the q-space. As there are three possible polarizations, the number of modes of vibration with wave numbers less than $q$ is

$$
\mathcal{N}=3 \cdot \frac{4}{3} \pi q^{3}\left(\frac{2 \pi}{L}\right)^{-3}=\frac{L^{3} q^{3}}{2 \pi^{2}} .
$$

Assuming all the modes have the same sound velocity $v$, we have $q=\frac{\omega}{v}$ and the density of state

$$
D(\omega)=\frac{d \mathcal{N}}{d \omega}=\frac{3 L^{3} q^{2}}{2 \pi^{2}} \frac{d q}{d \omega}=\frac{3 V \omega^{2}}{2 \pi^{2} v^{3}} .
$$

Furthermore as $\mathcal{N}=3 N$, the Debye cutoff angular frequency is

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{D}}=\left(\frac{6 \pi^{2} N}{V}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}} v=\left(6 \pi^{2} \eta\right)^{\frac{1}{3}} v .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle R^{2}\right\rangle &=\frac{\hbar}{2 \rho v} \int_{0}^{\omega_{\mathrm{D}}} \omega^{-1} D(\omega) d \omega \\
&=\frac{3 \hbar \omega_{\mathrm{D}}^{2}}{8 \pi^{2} m \eta v^{3}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

1014.b.Solution:

$$

Assuming all the modes have the same sound velocity $v$, we have $q=\frac{\omega}{v}$ and the density of state

$$
D(\omega)=\frac{d \mathcal{N}}{d \omega}=\frac{3 L^{3} q^{2}}{2 \pi^{2}} \frac{d q}{d \omega}=\frac{3 V \omega^{2}}{2 \pi^{2} v^{3}} .
$$

Furthermore as $\mathcal{N}=3 N$, the Debye cutoff angular frequency is

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{D}}=\left(\frac{6 \pi^{2} N}{V}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}} v=\left(6 \pi^{2} \eta\right)^{\frac{1}{3}} v .

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}

&=\frac{3 \hbar \omega_{\mathrm{D}}^{2}}{8 \pi^{2} m \eta v^{3}} .
\end{aligned}
$$$d=1$. The Debye approximation gives

$$
\mathcal{N}=N=2 q\left(\frac{2 \pi}{L}\right)^{-1}=\frac{L q}{\pi}=\frac{L}{\pi} \frac{\omega}{v},
$$

and hence

$$
D(\omega)=\frac{L}{\pi v}
$$

and

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{D}}=\frac{\pi N v}{L}=\pi \eta v,
$$

where $\eta$ is the number of atoms per unit length of the one-dimensional lattice. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle R^{2}\right\rangle &=\frac{\hbar}{2 \rho L} \sum_{j} \omega_{j}^{-1}=\frac{\hbar}{2 \pi \rho v} \int_{0}^{\omega_{\mathrm{D}}} \frac{d \omega}{\omega} \\
&=\left.\frac{\hbar}{2 \pi m \eta v} \ln \omega\right|_{0} ^{\omega_{\mathrm{D}}}=\infty .
\end{aligned}
$$

Physically, $\omega \approx 0$ corresponds to the lattice atoms move together as a rigid body, for which $\left\langle y^{2}\right\rangle$ is zero, not $\sim \omega^{-1}$. Thus an experimental determination of $\left\langle R^{2}\right\rangle$ would not yield infinity but same finite value.

1015.b.Problem Statement:
Consider a two-dimensional square lattice with one atom of mass $m$ per lattice point interacting with only nearest neighbors with force constant $K$. [Take the phonon dispersion curve to be $\omega_{q}=\sqrt{\frac{4 K}{m}} \sin (q a / 2)$.]

At high temperature $\left(k_{\mathrm{B}} T \gg \hbar \omega\right)$, find the mean square displacement of an atom from its equilibrium position, and comment on the stability of two-dimensional crystals.
1015.b.Solution:
In the long-wavelength limit, $q \rightarrow 0$ and

$$
\omega_{q}=\sqrt{\frac{4 K}{m}} \sin \left(\frac{q a}{2}\right) \approx \sqrt{\frac{K}{m}} q a .
$$

The velocity of sound is then

$$
v=\frac{\omega_{q}}{q}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}} a,
$$

independent of $q$. In the Debye model, the number of modes with wave numbers less than $q$ is given by the area, measured in units of $\left(\frac{2 \pi}{L}\right)^{2}, L$ being the length of the square lattice, of a circle of radius $q$ with center at the origin in the q-space. As there are two possible polarizations, the number of normal modes with wave numbers less than $q$ is

$$
\mathcal{N}=2 \pi q^{2}\left(\frac{2 \pi}{L}\right)^{-2}=\frac{L^{2} q^{2}}{2 \pi}=\frac{S}{2 \pi} \frac{\omega^{2}}{v^{2}},
$$

where $S$ is the area of the lattice. Then the density of phonon states is

$$
D(\omega)=\frac{d \mathcal{N}}{d \omega}=\frac{S \omega}{\pi v^{2}}=\frac{S m \omega}{\pi a^{2} K} .
$$

The total internal energy of the lattice is

$$
U=\int_{0}^{\omega_{m}} \frac{\hbar \omega}{e^{\hbar \omega / k_{\mathrm{B}} T}} \cdot D(\omega) d \omega .
$$

At high temperature, $\hbar \omega \ll k_{\mathrm{B}} T$ and

$$
e^{\hbar \omega / k_{\mathrm{B}} T} \approx 1+\frac{\hbar \omega}{k_{\mathrm{B}} T} .
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
U & \approx \int_{0}^{\omega_{\mathrm{D}}} k_{\mathrm{B}} T D(\omega) d \omega \\
&=\frac{S k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{2 \pi v^{2}} \omega_{\mathrm{D}}^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

If there are $N$ atoms in the lattice, then

$$
\mathcal{N}=2 N=\frac{S}{2 \pi} \frac{\omega_{\mathrm{D}}^{2}}{v^{2}},
$$

giving

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{D}}^{2}=\frac{4 \pi N v^{2}}{S},
$$

and so

$$
U=2 N k_{\mathrm{B}} T .
$$

At the high temperature limit, the average potential energy is equal to the average kinetic energy, and hence half the total energy. If $\left\langle r^{2}\right\rangle$ is the mean square displacement of an atom, then

$$
\frac{N}{2} K\left\langle r^{2}\right\rangle=N k_{\mathrm{B}} T,
$$

giving

$$
\left\langle r^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{2 k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{K},
$$

where $K$ is the interatomic force constant. Thus $\left\langle r^{2}\right\rangle \propto T$. If $T$ increases from a low value, $\sqrt{\left\langle r^{2}\right\rangle}$ will became greater than the lattice constant and the lattice breaks up. Hence a two-dimensional lattice is not stable at high temperatures.

1024.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a vibrating solid.

Evaluate the Helmholtz free energy $F$ of a phonon mode of frequency $\omega$ at temperature $T$.
1024.a.Solution:
For a phonon mode of frequency $\omega$, the partition function is

$$
Z=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} e^{-\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) \hbar \omega / k_{\mathrm{B}} T}=\frac{e^{-\hbar \omega / 2 k_{\mathrm{B}} T}}{1-e^{-\hbar \omega / k_{\mathrm{B}} T}} .
$$

The Helmholtz free energy of a crystal is therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
F &=-k_{\mathrm{B}} T \ln Z \\
&=k_{\mathrm{B}} T\left[\frac{\hbar \omega}{2 k_{\mathrm{B}} T}+\ln \left(1-e^{-\hbar \omega / k_{\mathrm{B}} T}\right)\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

1027.a.Problem Statement:
A binary alloy consists of $N_{\mathrm{A}}$ metal atoms A and $N_{\mathrm{B}}$ metal atoms B. The atoms form a simple cubic lattice in which each atom interacts only with the six nearest-neighbor atoms. The interaction energies are $-J(J>0)$ for neighboring combination $\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{A}$ or $\mathrm{B}-\mathrm{B}$, and $+J$ for $\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{B}$ combination.

Calculate the mixing entropy of the alloy. Assume that $N=N_{\mathrm{A}}+$ $N_{\mathrm{B}} \gg 1$
1027.a.Solution:
The mixing entropy is

$$
S=k_{\mathrm{B}} \ln \Omega,
$$

where

$$
\Omega=\frac{N !}{N_{\mathrm{A}} ! N_{\mathrm{B}} !} .
$$

Using Stirling's formula

$$
\ln N ! \approx N \ln N,
$$

we have

$$
\ln \Omega \approx N_{\mathrm{A}} \ln \left(1+\frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N_{\mathrm{A}}}\right)+N_{\mathrm{B}} \ln \left(1+\frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N_{\mathrm{B}}}\right)
$$

and hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
S &=k_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{A}} \ln \left(1+\frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N_{\mathrm{A}}}\right)+k_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{B}} \ln \left(1+\frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N_{\mathrm{B}}}\right) \\
&=N k_{\mathrm{B}} \ln 2-\frac{N}{2} k_{\mathrm{B}}[(1+x) \ln (1+x)+(1-x) \ln (1-x)] .
\end{aligned}
$$
1027.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

1027.b.Problem Statement:
A binary alloy consists of $N_{\mathrm{A}}$ metal atoms A and $N_{\mathrm{B}}$ metal atoms B. The atoms form a simple cubic lattice in which each atom interacts only with the six nearest-neighbor atoms. The interaction energies are $-J(J>0)$ for neighboring combination $\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{A}$ or $\mathrm{B}-\mathrm{B}$, and $+J$ for $\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{B}$ combination.

Compute the total interaction energy assuming that the atoms are randomly distributed among the sites.
1027.b.Solution:
The mixing entropy is

$$
S=k_{\mathrm{B}} \ln \Omega,
$$

where

$$
\Omega=\frac{N !}{N_{\mathrm{A}} ! N_{\mathrm{B}} !} .
$$

Using Stirling's formula

$$
\ln N ! \approx N \ln N,
$$

we have

$$
\ln \Omega \approx N_{\mathrm{A}} \ln \left(1+\frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N_{\mathrm{A}}}\right)+N_{\mathrm{B}} \ln \left(1+\frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N_{\mathrm{B}}}\right)
$$

and hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
S &=k_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{A}} \ln \left(1+\frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N_{\mathrm{A}}}\right)+k_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{B}} \ln \left(1+\frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N_{\mathrm{B}}}\right) \\
&=N k_{\mathrm{B}} \ln 2-\frac{N}{2} k_{\mathrm{B}}[(1+x) \ln (1+x)+(1-x) \ln (1-x)] .
\end{aligned}
$$Since on average each atom will have as its nearest neighbors $\frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N}$ A-atoms and $\frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N}$ B-atoms and the proportions of $\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{B}$ atom in the lattice are $\frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N}, \frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N}$ respectively, the mean interaction energy $U$ of an atom with its nearest-neighbor atoms is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
U &=6\left[(-J) \frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N}+J \frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N}\right] \frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N}+6\left[(-J) \frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N}+J \frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N}\right] \frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N} \\
&=6\left[(-J) \frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}+N_{\mathrm{B}}^{2}}{N^{2}}+J \frac{2 N_{\mathrm{A}} N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N^{2}}\right] \\
&=-\frac{6 J}{N^{2}}\left(N_{\mathrm{A}}-N_{\mathrm{B}}\right)^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the total interaction energy $E$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E &=\frac{N}{2} U=-\frac{3 J}{N}\left(N_{\mathrm{A}}-N_{\mathrm{B}}\right)^{2} \\
&=-3 N J x^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$
1027.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

1027.c.Problem Statement:
A binary alloy consists of $N_{\mathrm{A}}$ metal atoms A and $N_{\mathrm{B}}$ metal atoms B. The atoms form a simple cubic lattice in which each atom interacts only with the six nearest-neighbor atoms. The interaction energies are $-J(J>0)$ for neighboring combination $\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{A}$ or $\mathrm{B}-\mathrm{B}$, and $+J$ for $\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{B}$ combination.

Compute the free energy of the system, $F$, as a function of $x$, where $N_{\mathrm{A}}=N(1+x) / 2$ and $N_{\mathrm{B}}=N(1-x) / 2$. Expand $F(x)$ up to the 4th order in $x$. Show that there is a critical temperature $T_{\mathrm{c}}$ above and below which the curve $F(x)$ has different characteristic shapes. Determine $T_{\mathrm{c}}$ and sketch $F$ as a function of $x$ for $T>T_{\mathrm{c}}, T=T_{\mathrm{c}}$ and $T<T_{\mathrm{c}}$.
1027.c.Solution:
The mixing entropy is

$$
S=k_{\mathrm{B}} \ln \Omega,
$$

where

$$
\Omega=\frac{N !}{N_{\mathrm{A}} ! N_{\mathrm{B}} !} .
$$

Using Stirling's formula

$$
\ln N ! \approx N \ln N,
$$

we have

$$
\ln \Omega \approx N_{\mathrm{A}} \ln \left(1+\frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N_{\mathrm{A}}}\right)+N_{\mathrm{B}} \ln \left(1+\frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N_{\mathrm{B}}}\right)
$$

and hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
S &=k_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{A}} \ln \left(1+\frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N_{\mathrm{A}}}\right)+k_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{B}} \ln \left(1+\frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N_{\mathrm{B}}}\right) \\
&=N k_{\mathrm{B}} \ln 2-\frac{N}{2} k_{\mathrm{B}}[(1+x) \ln (1+x)+(1-x) \ln (1-x)] .
\end{aligned}
$$Since on average each atom will have as its nearest neighbors $\frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N}$ A-atoms and $\frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N}$ B-atoms and the proportions of $\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{B}$ atom in the lattice are $\frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N}, \frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N}$ respectively, the mean interaction energy $U$ of an atom with its nearest-neighbor atoms is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
U &=6\left[(-J) \frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N}+J \frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N}\right] \frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N}+6\left[(-J) \frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N}+J \frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}}{N}\right] \frac{N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N} \\
&=6\left[(-J) \frac{N_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}+N_{\mathrm{B}}^{2}}{N^{2}}+J \frac{2 N_{\mathrm{A}} N_{\mathrm{B}}}{N^{2}}\right] \\
&=-\frac{6 J}{N^{2}}\left(N_{\mathrm{A}}-N_{\mathrm{B}}\right)^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the total interaction energy $E$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E &=\frac{N}{2} U=-\frac{3 J}{N}\left(N_{\mathrm{A}}-N_{\mathrm{B}}\right)^{2} \\
&=-3 N J x^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$The free energy of the system $F$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
F &=E-T S \\
&=-3 N J x^{2}-N k_{\mathrm{B}} T \ln 2+\frac{N k_{\mathrm{B}} T x}{2} \ln \frac{1+x}{1-x}+\frac{N k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{2} \ln \left(1-x^{2}\right) \\
&=-N k_{\mathrm{B}} T \ln 2+\left(\frac{1}{2} N k_{\mathrm{B}} T-3 N J\right) x^{2}+\frac{1}{12} N k_{\mathrm{B}} T x^{4}+\cdots,
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have used

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ln (1+x)=x-\frac{1}{2} x^{2}+\frac{1}{3} x^{3}-\frac{1}{4} x^{4}+\cdots, \\
&\ln \frac{1+x}{1-x}=2\left(x+\frac{x^{3}}{3}+\frac{x^{5}}{5}+\cdots\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

To find the critical temperature $T_{\mathrm{c}}$ at which $F$ changes shape, consider $\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}$ and $\frac{\partial^{2} F}{\partial x^{2}}$ at a point, say $x=0$. These show that $T_{\mathrm{c}}$ is given by

$$
\frac{N}{2} k_{\mathrm{B}} T_{\mathrm{c}}-3 N J=0,
$$

i.e.,

$$
T_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{6 J}{k_{\mathrm{B}}} .
$$

In fact

$$
\left(\frac{\partial^{2} F}{\partial x^{2}}\right)_{x=0}\left\{\begin{array}{lll}
=0, & T=T_{\mathrm{c}} \\
>0, & T>T_{\mathrm{c}}, & F(0)=F_{\min }, \\
<0, & T<T_{\mathrm{c}}, & F(0)=F_{\max },
\end{array}\right.
$$

showing that $T_{\mathrm{c}}$ is the critical transition temperature. $F(x)$ is plotted for $T>T_{\mathrm{c}}$ and $T<T_{\mathrm{c}}$ in Fig. $1.11$.

1029.Problem Statement:
Metallic sodium crystalizes in body-centered cubic form, the length of the cube being $4.25 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~cm}$. Find the concentration of conduction electrons. Assume one conduction electron per atom. Adopting the freeelectron Fermi gas model for the conduction electrons, derive an expression for the Fermi energy (at $0 \mathrm{~K}$ ) and show that it depends only on the concentration of conduction electrons, but not on the mass of the crystal.

(Wisconsin )
1029.Solution:
A bcc lattice contains $\frac{2}{a^{3}}$ atoms per unit volume, so the concentration of conduction electrons is

$$
n=\frac{2}{\left(4.25 \times 10^{-8}\right)^{3}}=2.6 \times 10^{22} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3} .
$$

According to Fermi's free-electron gas model, the number of electrons in a volume $V$ with energies in the range $E$ to $E+d E$ is

$$
d N=C E^{1 / 2} f(E) d E
$$

with $c=4 \pi V(2 m)^{3 / 2} / \hbar^{3}, m$ being the electron mass. At $T=0 \mathrm{~K}$, the distribution function $f(E)$ is

$$
f(E)= \begin{cases}1 & \text { for } E \leq E_{F}, \\ 0 & \text { for } E>E_{F} .\end{cases}
$$

Hence the total number of electrons in $V$ is

$$
N=\int_{0}^{E_{\mathrm{F} 0}} C E^{1 / 2} d E=\frac{2}{3} C E_{\mathrm{F} 0}^{\frac{3}{2}} .
$$

where $E_{\mathrm{F} 0}$ is the Fermi energy at $T=0 \mathrm{~K}$. As $n=\frac{N}{V}$, the Fermi energy at $0 \mathrm{~K}$ is

$$
E_{\mathrm{F} 0}=\frac{h^{2}}{2 m}\left(\frac{3 n}{8 \pi}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left(3 \pi^{2} n\right)^{\frac{2}{3}} .
$$

For metallic sodium we have

$$
E_{\mathrm{F} 0}=\frac{\left(1.05 \times 10^{-27}\right)^{2}}{2 \times 9.1 \times 10^{-28}} \times \frac{\left(3 \pi^{2} \times 26 \times 10^{21}\right)^{2 / 3}}{1.6 \times 10^{-12}}=3.18 \mathrm{eV}
$$

The expression of $E_{\mathrm{F} 0}$ shows that it depends only on the concentration of conduction electrons, but not on the mass of the crystal.

1035.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a two-dimensional square lattice.

The kinetic energy of a free electron at a corner of the first Brillouin zone is larger than that of an electron at the midpoint of a side face of the zone by a factor $b$. Calculate $b$.
1035.a.Solution:
The kinetic energy of a free electron is

$$
E=\frac{-p^{2}}{2 m}=\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m} \propto k^{2} .
$$

The first Brillouin zone for a two-dimensional square lattice of lattice constant $a$ is a square in the $\mathbf{k}$-space of edge $\frac{2 \pi}{a}$, as shown in Fig. 1.16. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\overline{\Gamma M} &=\sqrt{2} \overline{\Gamma X}, \\
b &=\frac{E_{M}}{E_{X}}=\frac{\overline{\Gamma M}^{2}}{\overline{\Gamma X}^{2}}=2 .
\end{aligned}
$$

1035.b.Problem Statement:
Consider a two-dimensional square lattice.

The crystal potential of the corresponding material is

$$
V(x, y)=-2 V_{0}\left(\cos \frac{2 \pi x}{a}+\cos \frac{2 \pi y}{a}\right),
$$

where $V_{0}$ is a constant and $a$ is the lattice spacing. Find approximately the energy gap at the midpoint of the zone face.
1035.b.Solution:
The kinetic energy of a free electron is

$$
E=\frac{-p^{2}}{2 m}=\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m} \propto k^{2} .
$$

The first Brillouin zone for a two-dimensional square lattice of lattice constant $a$ is a square in the $\mathbf{k}$-space of edge $\frac{2 \pi}{a}$, as shown in Fig. 1.16. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\overline{\Gamma M} &=\sqrt{2} \overline{\Gamma X}, \\
b &=\frac{E_{M}}{E_{X}}=\frac{\overline{\Gamma M}^{2}}{\overline{\Gamma X}^{2}}=2 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Fig. $1.16$We can write

$$
V(x, y)=-V_{0}\left(e^{i 2 \pi x / a}+e^{-i 2 \pi x / a}+e^{i 2 \pi y / a}+e^{-i 2 \pi y / a}\right) .
$$

1040.d.Problem Statement:
Consider a one-dimensional periodic potential $U(x)$ viewed as an array of identical potential barriers $V(x)$ of width $a$, centered at the points $x=\pm n a$ where $n$ is an integer. The barrier $V(x)$, schematically drawn in Fig. 1.19, may be characterized by a transmission coefficient $t(k)$ and a 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_b8e2b1af07958c90efe7g-87.jpg?height=382&width=751&top_left_y=389&top_left_x=730)

Fig. $1.19$

reflection coefficient $r(k)$ for an electron incident on the barrier with energy $E=\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}$

Suppose the barriers are weak, i.e., $|t|=1$ and $|r|=0$, find a simple expression for the width of the energy gaps.
1040.d.Solution:
An electron of energy $E$ coming from the left of the single barrier can be represented by a wave

$$
\psi_{1}(x)= \begin{cases}e^{i k x}+r_{1} e^{-i k x}, & x \leq-\frac{a}{2} \\ t_{1} e^{i k x} & x \geq \frac{a}{2}\end{cases}
$$

$k$ being given by the relation $E=\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}$. An electron coming from the right can be represented by a wave

$$
\psi_{\mathrm{r}}(x)= \begin{cases}e^{-i k x}+r_{\mathrm{r}} e^{i k x}, & x \geq \frac{a}{2}, \\ t_{\mathrm{r}} e^{-i k x} & x \leq-\frac{a}{2}\end{cases}
$$

If $V(x)$ is not symmetrical, the reflection and transmission coefficients $r, t$ for the two cases are generally different. The general wave function for these regions is a linear combination of $\psi_{1}(x)$ and $\psi_{\mathrm{r}}(x)$ : 

$$
\psi(x)=A \psi_{1}(x)+B \psi_{\mathbf{r}}(x),
$$

$A, B$ being real constants.

Within the barrier $-\frac{a}{2} \leq x \leq \frac{a}{2}$, the wave function satisfies the onedimensional Schrödinger equation

$$
\left[-\frac{\hbar}{2 m} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}+V(x)\right] \psi=E \psi .
$$

For a periodic crystal potential

$$
U(x)=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} V(x+n a),
$$

the Hamiltonian within the region $-\frac{a}{2} \leq x \leq \frac{a}{2}$ is identical with that for a single barrier and we can make use of the Bloch theorem to find the general solution of the Schrödinger equation:

$$
\psi(x)=A \psi_{\mathrm{l}}(x)+B \psi_{\mathbf{r}}(x),
$$

with

$$
\psi(x+a)=e^{i K a} \psi(x),
$$

where $K$ is a positive real constant, and hence, on differentiation with respect to $x$,

$$
\psi^{\prime}(x+a)=e^{i K a} \psi^{\prime}(x) .
$$

Thus at $x=-\frac{a}{2}$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&A \psi_{1}\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)+B \psi_{\mathrm{r}}\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)=e^{i K a}\left[A \psi_{1}\left(-\frac{a}{2}\right)+B \psi_{\mathrm{r}}\left(-\frac{a}{2}\right)\right] \\
&A \psi_{1}^{\prime}\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)+B \psi_{\mathrm{r}}^{\prime}\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)=e^{i K a}\left[A \psi_{1}^{\prime}\left(-\frac{a}{2}\right)+B \psi_{\mathrm{r}}^{\prime}\left(-\frac{a}{2}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
\begin{aligned}
A\left[t_{1} \beta-\alpha\left(1+r_{1} \beta\right)\right]+B\left(1+r_{\mathrm{r}} \beta-t_{\mathrm{r}} \alpha \beta\right) &=0 \\
A\left[t_{1} \beta-\alpha\left(1-r_{1} \beta\right)\right]+B\left(-1+r_{\mathrm{r}} \beta+t_{\mathrm{r}} \alpha \beta\right) &=0
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\alpha=e^{i K a}, \quad \beta=e^{i k a} .
$$

Taking the sum and difference of the last two equations we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left(t_{1} \beta-\alpha\right) A+r_{\mathrm{r}} \beta B=0, \\
&-r_{1} \alpha \beta A+\left(1-t_{\mathrm{r}} \alpha \beta\right) B=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

For nontrivial solutions of $A, B$, the determinant of their coefficients must vanish, giving

$$
\left(t_{1} t_{\mathrm{r}}-r_{1} r_{\mathrm{r}}\right) e^{i k a}+e^{-i k a}=t_{1} e^{-i K a}+t_{\mathrm{r}} e^{i K a} .
$$

This gives the relation between the kinetic energy of the electron $E-V=$ $\frac{\hbar^{2} K^{2}}{2 m}$, and the wave vector $k$.

A crystal is usually symmetric so that $V(x)=V(-x)$ and hence $r_{1}=$ $r_{\mathrm{r}}=r, t_{1}=t_{\mathrm{r}}=t$. The above relation then becomes

$$
\left(t^{2}-r^{2}\right) e^{i k a}+e^{-i k a}=2 t \cos (K a) .
$$

If the electron is completely free, $r=0, t=1$, and the above gives

$$
\cos (k a)=\cos (K a),
$$

or

$$
k=K .
$$

This is the right answer since for $V=0$ we have $E=\frac{\hbar^{2} K^{2}}{2 m}$.

Consider an electron traveling from left to right through a single barrier, assumed symmetric. The continuity of the probability current density $-\frac{i \hbar}{2 m}\left(\psi^{*} \psi^{\prime}-\psi \psi^{\prime *}\right)$ applied to the regions $x \leq-\frac{a}{2}$ and $x \geq \frac{a}{2}$ gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi_{1}^{*} \psi_{1}^{\prime}-\psi_{1} \psi_{1}^{\prime *} &=\left(\alpha^{-1}+r^{*} \alpha\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\alpha+r \alpha^{-1}\right)-\left(\alpha+r \alpha^{-1}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\alpha^{-1}+r^{*} \alpha\right) \\
&=t^{*} \alpha^{-1} \frac{\partial}{\partial x}(t \alpha)-t \alpha \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(t^{*} \alpha^{-1}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\alpha=e^{i k x}$, and hence

$$
1-r r^{*}=t t^{*},
$$

or

$$
|r|^{2}+|t|^{2}=1
$$

as expected from energy conservation. Consider next two simultaneously traveling electrons of the same energy, one from left to right and the other from right to left, crossing the barrier. The probability current density is then zero everywhere, in particular at $x \leq-\frac{a}{2}$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left(\psi_{1}+\psi_{\mathrm{r}}\right)^{*} \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\psi_{1}+\psi_{\mathbf{r}}\right)-\left(\psi_{1}+\psi_{\mathbf{r}}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\psi_{1}+\psi_{\mathbf{r}}\right)^{*} \\
&=\left(\alpha^{-1}+r^{*} \alpha+t^{*} \alpha\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\alpha+r \alpha^{-1}+t \alpha^{-1}\right) \\
&\quad-\left(\alpha+r \alpha^{-1}+t \alpha^{-1}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\alpha^{-1}+r^{*} \alpha+t^{*} \alpha\right) \\
&=0
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
1-r r^{*}-t t^{*}-r^{*} t-r t^{*}=0 .
$$

Hence

$$
r^{*} t+r t^{*}=0,
$$

which means that $r^{*} t$ is purely imaginary. Let

$$
t=|t| e^{i \delta}, \quad r=i|r| e^{i \delta}
$$

and substitute these in Eq.
(1), which then gives

$$
\frac{\cos (k a+\delta)}{|t|}=\cos (K a) \text {. }
$$

With increasing electron energy, the transmission coefficient increases, i.e., $|t|$ increases toward unity as $k$ increases. Then the variation of the left-hand side of Eq.
(2) with $k$ is as shown in Fig. 1.20. However, as $\cos (K a)$ is confined to the region between $-1$ and 1 , certain values of $k$ are forbidden by Eq.
(2). These forbidden gaps are shown as shadowed areas in the figure. Hence the possible Bloch waves occurs only in bands of energies.

Consider an energy gap in the $k$-space with boundaries $k_{1}, k_{2}$ and midpoint at $k_{0}$ and width $2 \epsilon$. It can be seen from Fig. $1.20$ and Eq.
(2) that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\cos \left(k_{0} a+\delta\right)\right| &=1, \\
\left|\cos \left(k_{0} a+\delta+\epsilon a\right)\right| &=|t|,
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
k_{0} a+\delta=n \pi,
$$![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_41580ef03e6631735034g-01.jpg?height=431&width=876&top_left_y=359&top_left_x=646)

Fig. $1.20$

where $n$ is zero or an integer, and

$$
|\sin (n \pi+\epsilon a)|=\sqrt{1-|t|^{2}}=|r| \text {. }
$$

For a weak barrier, $|r| \rightarrow 0,|t| \rightarrow 1,|\delta| \rightarrow 0$, and as can be seen from Fig. 1.20, $\epsilon a \rightarrow 0$, so that

$$
k_{0}=\frac{1}{2}\left(k_{2}+k_{1}\right) \approx \frac{n \pi}{2 a}
$$

and

$$
|\sin (n \pi) \cos (\epsilon a)+\sin (\epsilon a) \cos (n \pi)| \approx \epsilon a=|r|
$$

i.e.,

$$
k_{2}-k_{1}=\frac{|r|}{a} .
$$

Hence the energy gap has width

$$
\Delta E=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left(k_{2}^{2}-k_{1}^{2}\right)=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m} k_{0}\left(k_{2}-k_{1}\right)=\frac{n \pi}{2} \frac{\hbar^{2}}{m a^{2}}|r|
$$

1041.c.Solution:
The coefficients in the expansion

$$
V(\mathbf{r})=\sum_{\mathbf{G}} V_{\mathbf{G}} e^{i \mathbf{G} \cdot \mathbf{r}}
$$

are

$$
V_{\mathbf{G}}=\frac{1}{v} \int_{\text {cell }} V(\mathbf{r}) e^{-i \mathbf{G} \cdot \mathbf{r}} d \mathbf{r},
$$

where $v$ is the volume of a unit cell.

If there are $n$ identical atoms in the unit cell with positions $\mathbf{d}_{1}, \mathbf{d}_{2}, \ldots$, $\mathbf{d}_{j}, \ldots, \mathbf{d}_{n}$, the periodic potential can be expressed as

$$
V(\mathbf{r})=\sum_{\mathbf{R}} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \Phi\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{R}-\mathbf{d}_{j}\right),
$$

where $\mathbf{R}$ is the position of a lattice point. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
V_{\mathbf{G}} &=\frac{1}{v} \int_{\text {cell }} e^{-i \mathbf{G} \cdot \mathbf{r}} \sum_{\mathbf{R}} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \Phi\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{R}-\mathbf{d}_{j}\right) d \mathbf{r} \\
&=\frac{1}{v} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \sum_{\mathbf{R}} \int_{\text {cell }} e^{-i \mathbf{G} \cdot \mathbf{r}} \Phi\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{R}-\mathbf{d}_{j}\right) d \mathbf{r} \\
&=\frac{1}{v} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \int_{\text {whole space }} e^{-i \mathbf{G} \cdot \mathbf{r}} \Phi\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{d}_{j}\right) d \mathbf{r} \\
&=\frac{1}{v} \int_{\text {whole space }} e^{-i \mathbf{G} \cdot \mathbf{r}} \Phi(\mathbf{r})\left(\sum_{j=1}^{n} e^{i \mathbf{G} \cdot \mathbf{d}_{j}}\right) d \mathbf{r} .
\end{aligned}
$$

In the expansion the sum $\sum_{j=1}^{n} e^{i \mathbf{G} \cdot \mathbf{d}_{j}}$ is the geometric structure factor. A unit cell of the hexagonal close-packed (hcp) structure contains two atoms at $\left(\begin{array}{lll}0 & 0 & 0\end{array}\right)$ and $\left(\frac{2}{3} \frac{1}{3} \frac{1}{2}\right)$. Thus for $\mathbf{G}=\frac{2 \pi}{c} \mathbf{b}_{3}$,

$$
\sum_{j=1}^{n} e^{i \mathbf{G} \cdot \mathbf{d}_{j}}=1+e^{\frac{i 2 \pi}{c} \cdot \frac{c}{2}}=0,
$$

and hence

$$
V_{\mathbf{G}}=0 .
$$

The first-order energy gap across this zone face is therefore

$$
2\left|V_{\mathbf{G}}\right|=0 .
$$

In the hcp structure, each energy band contains $2 \times 2 \times N=4 N$ states, where $N$ is the number of unit cells. However, for a solid made up of monovalent atoms, the total number of valence electrons in $2 N$, not enough to fill up the energy band completely. Hence it cannot be an insulator.

Conservation of lattice momentum requires

$$
\mathbf{k}^{\prime}=\mathbf{k}+\mathbf{k}_{\mathbf{p h}}+\mathbf{G} .
$$

The wavelength of visible light is about $5000 \AA$, giving $k_{\mathrm{ph}}=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}=$ $10^{5} \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$. The linear size of the Brillouin zone $\pi / a$ is of the order $10^{8} \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$. Hence $\mathbf{k}_{\mathrm{ph}}$ can affect the wave vector in the above formula only to a very small extent. Because of translation symmetry, a change of the wave vector by $\mathbf{G}$ does not generate any effect. Thus interband transitions can be considered as transitions between two energy bands with identical wave vectors, as shown by Fig. 1.21.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_41580ef03e6631735034g-03.jpg?height=621&width=794&top_left_y=1782&top_left_x=687)

Fig. $1.21$ Since $k_{\mathrm{F}}$ is much less than $k_{\mathrm{ZB}}$, one can make an estimation of the threshold wavelength for interband transitions using the free-electron approximation. From Fig. $1.21$ it can be seen that

$$
\hbar \omega_{\text {th }}=\hbar \frac{2 \pi c}{\lambda_{\text {th }}}=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m}\left(2 k_{\mathrm{ZB}}-k_{\mathrm{F}}\right)^{2}-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} k_{\mathrm{F}}^{2}=\frac{2 \hbar^{2}}{m} k_{\mathrm{B}}\left(k_{\mathrm{B}}-k_{\mathrm{F}}\right),
$$

which gives the threshold wavelength

$$
\lambda_{\mathrm{th}}=\frac{\pi m c}{\hbar k_{\mathrm{ZB}}\left(k_{\mathrm{ZB}}-k_{\mathrm{F}}\right)},
$$

where

$$
k_{\mathrm{F}}=\left(3 \pi^{2} n\right)^{1 / 3}=\left(3 \pi^{2} \frac{2}{a^{3}}\right)^{1 / 3}=\frac{1}{a}\left(6 \pi^{2}\right)^{1 / 3} .
$$

The reciprocal lattice of a bcc lattice with edge $a$ is an fcc lattice with edge $\frac{4 \pi}{a}$. Thus $k_{\mathrm{ZB}}$ is a quarter of the diagonal of the fcc face,

$$
k_{\mathrm{ZB}}=\frac{1}{4} \sqrt{2} \frac{4 \pi}{a}=\frac{\sqrt{2} \pi}{a} .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda_{\text {th }} &=\frac{m c}{\hbar} \frac{a^{2}}{2 \pi-\sqrt{2}\left(6 \pi^{2}\right)^{1 / 3}} \\
&=\frac{m c^{2}}{\hbar c} \frac{a^{2}}{2 \pi-\sqrt{2}\left(6 \pi^{2}\right)^{1 / 3}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

With $\hbar c=1.97 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{eV} \cdot \AA, m c^{2}=0.511 \mathrm{MeV}, a=4.23 \AA$, we obtain

$$
\lambda_{\text {th }}=6034 \AA .
$$

1044.a.Problem Statement:
Consider an intrinsic semiconductor. Let $\varepsilon$ be the energy of an electron. Let $g_{\mathrm{C}}(\varepsilon)$ be the density of states in the conduction band, and $g_{\mathrm{V}}(\varepsilon)$ be the density of states in the valence band (see Fig. 1.24). Assume $\varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}} \gg k_{\mathrm{B}} T$, $\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{V}} \gg k_{\mathrm{B}} T$, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
&g_{\mathrm{C}}(\varepsilon)=C_{1}\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}\right)^{1 / 2}, \\
&g_{\mathrm{V}}(\varepsilon)=C_{2}\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{V}}-\varepsilon\right)^{1 / 2},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\varepsilon_{C}$ represents the energy of the bottom of the conduction band and $\varepsilon_{V}$ the top of the valence band. The Fermi energy is $\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}$.

Find an expression for $n$, the number of electrons in the conduction band, in terms of $k_{\mathrm{B}}, T, C_{1}, \varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}, \varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}$ and a dimensionless definite integral.
1044.a.Solution:
The concentration of electrons in the conduction band is given by

$$
n=\int_{\varepsilon_{\mathbf{C}}}^{\infty} f(\varepsilon) g_{\mathrm{C}}(\varepsilon) d \varepsilon
$$

with

$$
f(\varepsilon)=\frac{1}{e^{\beta\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{F}\right)}+1} \text {, }
$$

where $\beta=\left(k_{\mathrm{B}} T\right)^{-1}$. Since $\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}} \geq \varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}} \gg k_{\mathrm{B}} T$

$$
f(\varepsilon) \approx e^{-\beta\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{F}\right)}
$$

Setting $x=\beta\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{C}\right)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
n & \approx C_{1} \int_{\varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}}^{\infty} e^{-\beta\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}\right)}\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} d \varepsilon \\
&=C_{1} \beta^{-3 / 2} e^{-\beta\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}\right)} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-x} x^{1 / 2} d x \\
&=C_{1}\left(k_{\mathrm{B}} T\right)^{3 / 2} e^{-\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}\right) / k_{\mathrm{B}} T} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-x} x^{1 / 2} d x
\end{aligned}
$$
1044.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics
1044.a.Final Answer: $$C_{1}\left(k_{\mathrm{B}} T\right)^{3 / 2} e^{-\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}\right) / k_{\mathrm{B}} T} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-x} x^{1 / 2} d x$$

1044.c.Problem Statement:
Consider an intrinsic semiconductor. Let $\varepsilon$ be the energy of an electron. Let $g_{\mathrm{C}}(\varepsilon)$ be the density of states in the conduction band, and $g_{\mathrm{V}}(\varepsilon)$ be the density of states in the valence band (see Fig. 1.24). Assume $\varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}} \gg k_{\mathrm{B}} T$, $\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{V}} \gg k_{\mathrm{B}} T$, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
&g_{\mathrm{C}}(\varepsilon)=C_{1}\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}\right)^{1 / 2}, \\
&g_{\mathrm{V}}(\varepsilon)=C_{2}\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{V}}-\varepsilon\right)^{1 / 2},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\varepsilon_{C}$ represents the energy of the bottom of the conduction band and $\varepsilon_{V}$ the top of the valence band. The Fermi energy is $\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}$.

Find an explicit expression for $\varepsilon_{\mathbf{F}}(T)$.
1044.c.Solution:
The concentration of electrons in the conduction band is given by

$$
n=\int_{\varepsilon_{\mathbf{C}}}^{\infty} f(\varepsilon) g_{\mathrm{C}}(\varepsilon) d \varepsilon
$$

with

$$
f(\varepsilon)=\frac{1}{e^{\beta\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{F}\right)}+1} \text {, }
$$

where $\beta=\left(k_{\mathrm{B}} T\right)^{-1}$. Since $\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}} \geq \varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}} \gg k_{\mathrm{B}} T$

$$
f(\varepsilon) \approx e^{-\beta\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{F}\right)}
$$

Setting $x=\beta\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{C}\right)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
n & \approx C_{1} \int_{\varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}}^{\infty} e^{-\beta\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}\right)}\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} d \varepsilon \\
&=C_{1} \beta^{-3 / 2} e^{-\beta\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}\right)} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-x} x^{1 / 2} d x \\
&=C_{1}\left(k_{\mathrm{B}} T\right)^{3 / 2} e^{-\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}\right) / k_{\mathrm{B}} T} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-x} x^{1 / 2} d x
\end{aligned}
$$The probability of hole occupation of a state is $1-f(\varepsilon)$. As $\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}-\varepsilon \geq \varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{V}} \gg k_{\mathrm{B}} T$

$$
1-f(\varepsilon) \approx \frac{e^{\beta\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{F}\right)}}{e^{-\beta\left(\varepsilon_{F}-\varepsilon\right)}+1} \approx e^{\beta\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{F}\right)} .
$$

Setting $x=-\beta\left(\varepsilon-\varepsilon_{V}\right)$, we have the concentration of holes in the valence band

$$
\begin{aligned}
p &=C_{2} \beta^{-3 / 2} e^{\beta\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{V}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}\right)} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-x} x^{1 / 2} d x \\
&=C_{2}\left(k_{\mathrm{B}} T\right)^{3 / 2} e^{-\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{V}}\right) / k_{\mathrm{B}} T} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-x} x^{1 / 2} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

For an intrinsic semiconductor, $n=p$. Hence

$$
C_{1} e^{-\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}\right) / k_{\mathrm{B}} T}=C_{2} e^{-\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}-\varepsilon_{\mathrm{V}}\right) / k_{\mathrm{B}} T}
$$

giving

$$
\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{C}}+\varepsilon_{\mathrm{V}}-k_{\mathrm{B}} T \ln \frac{C_{1}}{C_{2}}\right)
$$

1045.a.Problem Statement:
At room temperature, $k_{\mathrm{B}} T / e=26 \mathrm{mV}$. A sample of cadmium sulfide displays a mobile carrier density of $10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$ and a mobility coefficient $\mu=10^{2} \mathrm{~cm}^{2} /$ volt sec.

Calculate the electrical conductivity of this sample.

1045.b.Problem Statement:
At room temperature, $k_{\mathrm{B}} T / e=26 \mathrm{mV}$. A sample of cadmium sulfide displays a mobile carrier density of $10^{16} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$ and a mobility coefficient $\mu=10^{2} \mathrm{~cm}^{2} /$ volt sec.

The carriers are continuously trapped into immobile sites and then being thermally reionized into mobile states. If the average free lifetime in a mobile state is $10^{-5}$ second, what is the rms distance a carrier diffuses between successive trappings?
1045.b.Solution:
The electrical conductivity is given by $\sigma=n e \mu$. With $n=10^{22} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$, $e=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}, \mu=10^{-2} \mathrm{~m}^{2} \mathrm{~V}^{-1} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$, we have for the material $\sigma=$ $16 \Omega^{-1} \mathrm{~m}^{-1}$.The law of equipartition of energy

$$
\frac{1}{2} m \bar{v}_{x}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m \bar{v}_{y}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m \bar{v}_{z}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} k_{\mathrm{B}} T
$$

gives

$$
\frac{1}{2} m \bar{v}^{2}=\frac{3}{2} k_{\mathrm{B}} T,
$$

or

$$
\bar{v}^{2}=\sqrt{\frac{3 k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{m}} .
$$

The rms distance $l$ between successive trappings is given by

$$
l^{2}=\bar{v}^{2} t^{2} .
$$

Hence

$$
l=\sqrt{\frac{3 k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{m}} t=\sqrt{3\left(\frac{k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{e}\right) \frac{e}{m}} t .
$$

With $\frac{k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{e}=26 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~V}, \frac{e}{m}=1.76 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{C} \mathrm{kg}^{-1}, t=10^{-5} \mathrm{~s}$, we have $l=1.17 \mathrm{~m}$.

If the charge carriers have an effective mass equal to $0.1$ times the mass of a free electron, what is the average time between successive scatterings?

(Wisconsin )
1045.c.Solution:
The electrical conductivity is given by $\sigma=n e \mu$. With $n=10^{22} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$, $e=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}, \mu=10^{-2} \mathrm{~m}^{2} \mathrm{~V}^{-1} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$, we have for the material $\sigma=$ $16 \Omega^{-1} \mathrm{~m}^{-1}$.The law of equipartition of energy

$$
\frac{1}{2} m \bar{v}_{x}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m \bar{v}_{y}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m \bar{v}_{z}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} k_{\mathrm{B}} T
$$

gives

$$
\frac{1}{2} m \bar{v}^{2}=\frac{3}{2} k_{\mathrm{B}} T,
$$

or

$$
\bar{v}^{2}=\sqrt{\frac{3 k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{m}} .
$$

The rms distance $l$ between successive trappings is given by

$$
l^{2}=\bar{v}^{2} t^{2} .
$$

Hence

$$
l=\sqrt{\frac{3 k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{m}} t=\sqrt{3\left(\frac{k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{e}\right) \frac{e}{m}} t .
$$

With $\frac{k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{e}=26 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~V}, \frac{e}{m}=1.76 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{C} \mathrm{kg}^{-1}, t=10^{-5} \mathrm{~s}$, we have $l=1.17 \mathrm{~m}$.The free electron model of metals gives

$$
\sigma=\frac{n e^{2}\langle\tau\rangle}{m^{*}},
$$

where $m^{*}$ is the effective mass of an electron. Then the average time between successive scatterings is

1046.Problem Statement: Determine the form of the temperature dependence of the electrical conductivity $\frac{n e^{2} \tau}{m}$ (where $\tau=$ effective collision time) of a semiconductor in a temperature domain where the density $n$ of free carriers is constant and the dominant scattering mechanism is Rutherford scattering from a constant and small number of charged impurities.
1046.Solution:
The differential cross section for Rutherford scattering of a particle of charge $e$, mass $m$, and velocity $v$ by an impurity nucleus of charge $Z e$ per unit solid angle is

$$
\frac{d \phi}{d \Omega}=\left(\frac{Z e^{2}}{8 \pi \epsilon m v^{2}}\right)^{2} \operatorname{cosec}^{4}\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)=R^{2} \operatorname{cosec}^{4}\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right),
$$

where $\epsilon$ is the permittivity of the semiconductor material and $\theta$ is the scattering angle as shown in Fig. 1.25. The probability per unit time of scattering through a scattering angle between $\theta$ and $\theta+d \theta$ is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
d P=N_{\mathrm{I}} v d \phi &=2 \pi N_{\mathrm{I}} v R^{2} \frac{\sin \theta d \theta}{\sin ^{4}\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)} \\
&=8 \pi N_{\mathrm{I}} v R^{2} \frac{d(1-\cos \theta)}{(1-\cos \theta)^{2}},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $N_{\mathrm{I}}$ is the number of impurity atoms per unit volume.

In the expression for electrical conductivity,

$$
\sigma=\frac{n e^{2} \tau}{m},
$$

the effective collision time, or the relaxation time, $\tau$, is identical with the mean free time between collisions $\tau_{\mathrm{c}}$ only if the scattering is isotropic, which is not the case for Rutherford scattering. Instead,

$$
\tau=\tau_{\mathrm{c}}(1-\langle\cos \theta\rangle)^{-1},
$$

where $\langle\cos \theta\rangle$ is the average of the cosine of the scattering angle $\theta$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{\tau} &=\frac{\langle 1-\cos \theta\rangle}{\tau_{\mathrm{c}}} \approx \int(1-\cos \theta) d P \\
&=8 \pi N_{\mathrm{I}} v R^{2} \int_{\theta_{\min }}^{\theta_{\max }} \frac{d(1-\cos \theta)}{(1-\cos \theta)} \\
&=\frac{Z^{2} e^{4} N_{\mathrm{I}}}{8 \pi \epsilon^{2} m^{2} v^{3}} \ln \left(\frac{1-\cos \theta_{\max }}{1-\cos \theta_{\min }}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, treating the logarithmic function as approximately constant,

$$
\frac{1}{\tau} \propto N_{\mathrm{I}} v^{-3} .
$$

Since each degree of freedom of the carrier has an average energy $\frac{1}{2} k_{\mathrm{B}} T$,

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{3 k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{m}} \propto T^{\frac{1}{2}}
$$

and

$$
\frac{1}{\tau} \propto T^{-\frac{3}{2}} .
$$

It follows that the electric conductivity

$$
\sigma=\frac{n e^{2} \tau}{m} \propto T^{\frac{3}{2}} .
$$

For an intrinsic semiconductor, $n=p$ and the current density is

and the current is

$$
I=j S=1.6 \times 10^{3} \times 10^{4}=0.16 \mathrm{~A}=160 \mathrm{~mA} .

The diffusion coefficient $D$ is given by the Einstein relation

$$
\frac{D}{\mu}=\frac{k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{e} .

1050.a.Problem Statement:
The low temperature $(T \sim 4 \mathrm{~K})$ optical absorption spectrum of very pure InP, a direct gap semiconductor, is shown in Fig. 1.27, where intensity of absorption is plotted as a function of phonon energy (full lines). There

Fig. $1.27$

are a few lower intensity peaks between $\mathrm{C}$ and $\mathrm{A}$; these have not been shown for simplicity.

What is the physical origin of the absorption continuum with threshold at $A$, and of the peak at $C$ ?

The energies $E_{\mathrm{A}}$ and $E_{\mathrm{C}}$ are $1.400 \mathrm{eV}$ and $1.386 \mathrm{eV}$ respectively. The static dielectric constant of $\operatorname{InP}$ is 9.6, and the hole in $\operatorname{InP}$ is much lighter than the electron $\left(m_{\mathrm{h}}^{*} \ll m_{\mathrm{e}}^{*}\right)$. From the above information calculate
1050.a.Solution:
The absorption continuum with threshold at $A$ is caused by the absorption of a photon from the incident beam by a valence electron, which then jumps into the conduction band. The process can take place if $h 
u \geq E_{\mathrm{g}}$, the energy gap. The lower photon energy limit corresponds to the threshold. The excited electron in the conduction band and the hole left in the valence band both behave as free particles.

If the incident photon energy $h 
u<E_{\mathrm{g}}$, it is not sufficient to excite a valence electron into the conduction band. However, it may still be sufficient to excite an electrons from some atom of the crystal leaving behind a hole, the electron-hole pair forming a bound state, called an exciton, in which the two particles revolve around their center of mass. The photon involved in exciton absorption has energy $h 
u=E_{\mathrm{g}}-E_{	ext {ex }}$, where $E_{	ext {ex }}$ is the exciton binding energy, usually about $0.01 \mathrm{eV}$. The exciton spectrum consists of a sharp line, slightly below the threshold of the absorption continuum, shown as the sharp peak at $\mathrm{C}$ in Fig. 1.27. The line may often be broadened by interaction of the exciton with impurities and other effects.
