1052.a.Problem Statement:
The orienting tendency of an electric field $E$ on a permanent dipole is opposed by thermal agitation.

Using classical statistical mechanics, calculate the total polarization of a gas of $N$ independent permanent dipoles of moment $P$.
1052.a.Solution:
In a gas of independent dipoles, the latter are able to rotate freely. The potential energy of a dipole of moment $\mathbf{p}$ in an applied electric field $\mathbf{E}$ is

$$
V=-\mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{E}=-p E \cos \theta,
$$

where $\theta$ is the angle it makes with the direction of the field. Classical statistical mechanics gives that the probability of finding the dipole along the $\theta$ direction is given by the Boltzmann distribution function 

$$
f(\theta)=e^{-V / k_{\mathrm{B}} T}=\exp \left(\frac{p E \cos \theta}{k_{\mathrm{B}} T}\right)
$$

The average value of $p$ along the direction of the field is then

$$
\langle p \cos \theta\rangle=\frac{\int p \cos \theta f(\theta) d \Omega}{\int f(\theta) d \Omega}
$$

with $d \Omega=2 \pi \sin \theta d \theta$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle p \cos \theta\rangle &=\frac{\int_{0}^{\pi} p \cos \theta \exp \left(\frac{p E \cos \theta}{k_{\mathrm{B}} T}\right) 2 \pi \sin \theta d \theta}{\int_{0}^{\pi} \exp \left(\frac{p E \cos \theta}{k_{\mathrm{B}} T}\right) 2 \pi \sin \theta d \theta} \\
&=\frac{p \int_{-1}^{1} e^{\beta x} x d x}{\int_{-1}^{1} e^{\beta x} d x} \\
&=\frac{p}{\beta}(\beta \operatorname{coth} \beta-1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $x=\cos \theta, \beta=\frac{p E}{k_{\mathrm{B}} T}$.

As there are $N$ independent dipoles in the gas the total polarization is

$$
P=N\langle p \cos \theta\rangle=\frac{N k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{E}\left(\frac{p E}{k_{\mathrm{B}} T} \operatorname{coth} \frac{p E}{k_{\mathrm{B}} T}-1\right)
$$
1052.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics
1052.a.Final Answer: $$\frac{N k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{E}\left(\frac{p E}{k_{\mathrm{B}} T} \operatorname{coth} \frac{p E}{k_{\mathrm{B}} T}-1\right)$$

1053.c.Problem Statement: Calculate the wavelength cutoff for $\mathrm{Na}$ metal if the volume of a primitive unit cell in $\mathrm{Na}$ is $35 \times 10^{-30} \mathrm{~m}^{3}$.
1053.c.Solution:
Take the $x$-axis parallel to the applied electric field $\mathbf{E}=\mathbf{E}_{0} e^{i \omega t}$. The displacement of a free electron from its neutral position, taken as the origin, is given by

$$
m \frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}=-e E_{0} e^{i \omega t} .
$$

Try a solution of the form $x=x_{0} e^{i \omega t}$. Substitution gives

$$
x_{0}=\frac{e E_{0}}{m \omega^{2}} .
$$

The dipole moment per unit volume, or the polarization, of the electron gas is by definition

$$
P=-n e x=-\frac{n e^{2}}{m \omega^{2}} E_{0} e^{i \omega t}=-\frac{n e^{2}}{m \omega^{2}} E
$$

The (relative) dielectric constant $\epsilon$ is then

$$
\epsilon=\frac{D}{\epsilon_{0} E}=\frac{\epsilon_{0} E+P}{\epsilon_{0} E}=1-\frac{n e^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} m} \frac{1}{\omega^{2}}=1-\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega^{2}}
$$

where $\omega_{\mathrm{p}}=\sqrt{\frac{n e^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} m}}$ is the plasma (angular) frequency of the gas.

The refractive index of a substance is $n=\sqrt{\epsilon}$. For light of frequency $\omega<\omega_{\mathrm{p}}$ incident on a metal of plasma frequency $\omega_{\mathbf{p}}, n$ is imaginary. This means that such light cannot be transmitted through the metal but is totally reflected from its surface. Thus metals are opaque to light for which $\omega<\omega_{\mathrm{p}}$.

The sodium atom has valency one and in the metallic state each atom contributes one conduction electron. As each primitive cell contains one atom, the number density of conduction electrons is

$$
n=\frac{1}{35 \times 10^{-30}}=2.86 \times 10^{28} \mathrm{~m}^{-3} .
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{\mathbf{p}}^{2} &=4 \pi c^{2} n\left(\frac{e^{2}}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0} m c^{2}}\right) \\
&=4 \pi \times\left(3 \times 10^{8}\right)^{2} \times 2.86 \times 10^{28} \times 2.82 \times 10^{-15} \\
&=9.12 \times 10^{31} \mathrm{~s}^{-2},
\end{aligned}
$$

and the cutoff angular frequency is

$$
\omega=\omega_{\mathrm{p}}=9.55 \times 10^{15} \mathrm{~s}^{-1} .
$$

Hence the cutoff wavelength is

$$
\lambda=\frac{2 \pi c}{\omega}=2.0 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~m}=2000 \AA .
$$
1053.c.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

1055.a.Problem Statement:
Let a dielectric be described as $N$ valence electrons per unit volume, bound to ions harmonically with angular frequency $\omega_{0}$. It is in a uniform magnetic field B directed along the $z$-axis. Monochromatic light of frequency $\omega$ is sent through the dielectric along the $z$-direction.

If the light is circularly polarized, find the indices of refraction.
1055.a.Solution:
The equation of motion for a valence electron is

$$
m \frac{d^{2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}=-e \mathbf{E}-e \mathbf{V} \times \mathbf{B}-m \omega_{0}^{2} \mathbf{r},
$$

where $\mathbf{r}$ is the displacement of the electron from its equilibrium position. The collective motion of the $N$ valence electrons generates a polarization

$$
\mathbf{P}=-N e \mathbf{r} .
$$

The equation of the polarization is accordingly

$$
-\frac{m}{N e} \frac{d^{2} \mathbf{P}}{d t^{2}}=-e \mathbf{E}-e\left(-\frac{1}{N e} \frac{d \mathbf{P}}{d t}\right) \times \mathbf{B}+\frac{m \omega_{0}^{2}}{N e} \mathbf{P} .
$$

As $\mathbf{E} \sim e^{i \omega t}$, we have $\mathbf{P} \sim e^{i \omega t}$ and $\frac{d}{d t}=i \omega$. Substitution in the above gives or

$$
\frac{m \omega^{2}}{N e} \mathbf{P}=-e \mathbf{E}-\frac{i \omega \mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{P}}{N}+\frac{m \omega_{0}^{2}}{N e} \mathbf{P},
$$

$$
\mathbf{E}=\frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathbf{p}}^{2}} \mathbf{P}+\frac{i \omega}{N e} \mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{P},
$$

where $\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}=\frac{N e^{2}}{m \epsilon_{0}}$. As $\mathbf{B}=(0,0, B)$, the above can be written as

$$
\left(\begin{array}{l}
E_{x} \\
E_{y} \\
E_{z}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}} & \frac{i \omega}{N e} B & 0 \\
-\frac{i \omega}{N e} B & \frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & \frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
P_{x} \\
P_{y} \\
P_{z}
\end{array}\right) .
$$

Maxwell's equations for free space

$$
\nabla \times \mathbf{E}=-\dot{\mathbf{B}}, \quad \nabla \times \mathbf{H}=\dot{\mathbf{D}}, \quad \nabla \cdot \mathbf{D}=0
$$

with $\mathbf{B}=\mu_{0} \mathbf{H}, \mathbf{D}=\epsilon_{0} \mathbf{E}+\mathbf{P}$ give

$$
\mu_{0} \epsilon_{0} \ddot{\mathbf{E}}-\nabla^{2} \mathbf{E}=\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0}} \nabla(\nabla \cdot \mathbf{P})-\mu_{0} \ddot{\mathbf{P}} .
$$

With $\mathbf{E}=E_{0} e^{i(\omega t-k \cdot \mathbf{r})}, \mathbf{P}=P_{0} e^{i(\omega t-k \cdot \mathbf{r})}, \mathbf{k}=k \mathbf{e}_{z}$, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}}=-\omega^{2}, \quad \nabla^{2} \mathbf{E}=-k^{2} \mathbf{E}, \\
\nabla \cdot \mathbf{P}=-i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{P}=-i k P_{z}, \quad \nabla(\nabla \cdot \mathbf{P})=-k^{2} P_{z} \mathbf{e}_{z},
\end{gathered}
$$

and thus

$$
\epsilon_{0}\left(k^{2} c^{2}-\omega^{2}\right) \mathbf{E}=-k^{2} c^{2} P_{z} \mathbf{e}_{z}+\omega^{2} \mathbf{P}
$$

since $\mu_{0} \epsilon_{0}=c^{-2}$. Letting $\chi=\frac{k^{2} c^{2}}{\omega^{2}}-1$, we can write the above as

$$
\epsilon_{0} \chi \mathbf{E}=P_{x} \mathbf{e}_{x}+P_{y} \mathbf{e}_{y}-\chi P_{z} \mathbf{e}_{z},
$$

or

$$
\left(\begin{array}{c}
E_{x} \\
E_{y} \\
E_{z}
\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0} \chi}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -\chi
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
P_{x} \\
P_{y} \\
P_{z}
\end{array}\right) .
$$

The above two matrix equations combine to give

$$
\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0} \chi} & \frac{i \omega}{N e} B & 0 \\
-\frac{i \omega}{N e} B & \frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0} \chi} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & \frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}+\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0}}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
P_{x} \\
P_{y} \\
P_{z}
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

In general $\frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}+\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0}} \neq 0$, hence $P_{z}=0$ and so $E_{z}=0$. This means that an incident plane wave will remain a plane wave. The condition for nonvanishing solutions is that determinant of the square matrix in the equation for $\mathbf{P}$ must vanish, giving

$$
\frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathbf{p}}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0} \chi_{\pm}}=\pm \frac{\omega B}{N e} .
$$

Thus there are two refractive indices

$$
n_{\pm}=\frac{c k_{\pm}}{\omega}=\sqrt{1+\chi_{\pm}}=\sqrt{1+\frac{N e \omega_{\mathbf{p}}^{2}}{N e\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right) \mp \epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2} \omega B}} .
$$

Corresponding to $n_{\pm}$we have

$$
\frac{\omega B}{N e} P_{x}=\mp \frac{i \omega B}{N e} P_{y}, \quad \text { or } \quad P_{y}=\pm i P_{x}
$$

and hence the amplitudes

$$
P_{\pm}=C_{\pm}\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
\pm i \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

where $C_{+}, C_{-}$are constants. Similarly,

$$
E_{\pm}=\frac{C_{\pm}}{\epsilon_{0} \chi_{\pm}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
\pm i \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

Since the factors $\pm i$ correspond to additional phase angles $\pm \frac{\pi}{2}$, the above shows that $E_{+}, E_{-}$are right-hand and left-hand circularly polarized waves with indices of refraction $n_{+}, n_{-}$respectively.
(Right-hand rotation means that looking against the direction of light, E rotates clockwise. For $E_{+}$, $E_{y}=i E_{x}$, or $E_{x}=\frac{E_{0}}{2} \cos \omega t=\frac{E_{0}}{2} \cos (-\omega t), E_{y}=\frac{E_{0}}{2} \cos \left(\omega t+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=$ $\left.\frac{E_{0}}{2} \sin (-\omega t).\right)$
1055.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

1055.b.Problem Statement:
Let a dielectric be described as $N$ valence electrons per unit volume, bound to ions harmonically with angular frequency $\omega_{0}$. It is in a uniform magnetic field B directed along the $z$-axis. Monochromatic light of frequency $\omega$ is sent through the dielectric along the $z$-direction.

If the light is linearly polarized, calculate the angle through which the polarization rotates as the wave propagates a distance $z$ in the dielectric (you may assume that $\Delta n \ll n$, where $\Delta n=n_{\mathrm{R}}-n_{\mathrm{L}}$ and $\left.n=\left(n_{\mathrm{R}}+n_{\mathrm{L}}\right) / 2\right)$.
1055.b.Solution:
The equation of motion for a valence electron is

$$
m \frac{d^{2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}=-e \mathbf{E}-e \mathbf{V} \times \mathbf{B}-m \omega_{0}^{2} \mathbf{r},
$$

where $\mathbf{r}$ is the displacement of the electron from its equilibrium position. The collective motion of the $N$ valence electrons generates a polarization

$$
\mathbf{P}=-N e \mathbf{r} .
$$

The equation of the polarization is accordingly

$$
-\frac{m}{N e} \frac{d^{2} \mathbf{P}}{d t^{2}}=-e \mathbf{E}-e\left(-\frac{1}{N e} \frac{d \mathbf{P}}{d t}\right) \times \mathbf{B}+\frac{m \omega_{0}^{2}}{N e} \mathbf{P} .
$$

As $\mathbf{E} \sim e^{i \omega t}$, we have $\mathbf{P} \sim e^{i \omega t}$ and $\frac{d}{d t}=i \omega$. Substitution in the above gives or

$$
\frac{m \omega^{2}}{N e} \mathbf{P}=-e \mathbf{E}-\frac{i \omega \mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{P}}{N}+\frac{m \omega_{0}^{2}}{N e} \mathbf{P},
$$

$$
\mathbf{E}=\frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathbf{p}}^{2}} \mathbf{P}+\frac{i \omega}{N e} \mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{P},
$$

where $\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}=\frac{N e^{2}}{m \epsilon_{0}}$. As $\mathbf{B}=(0,0, B)$, the above can be written as

$$
\left(\begin{array}{l}
E_{x} \\
E_{y} \\
E_{z}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}} & \frac{i \omega}{N e} B & 0 \\
-\frac{i \omega}{N e} B & \frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & \frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
P_{x} \\
P_{y} \\
P_{z}
\end{array}\right) .
$$

Maxwell's equations for free space

$$
\nabla \times \mathbf{E}=-\dot{\mathbf{B}}, \quad \nabla \times \mathbf{H}=\dot{\mathbf{D}}, \quad \nabla \cdot \mathbf{D}=0
$$

with $\mathbf{B}=\mu_{0} \mathbf{H}, \mathbf{D}=\epsilon_{0} \mathbf{E}+\mathbf{P}$ give

$$
\mu_{0} \epsilon_{0} \ddot{\mathbf{E}}-\nabla^{2} \mathbf{E}=\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0}} \nabla(\nabla \cdot \mathbf{P})-\mu_{0} \ddot{\mathbf{P}} .
$$

With $\mathbf{E}=E_{0} e^{i(\omega t-k \cdot \mathbf{r})}, \mathbf{P}=P_{0} e^{i(\omega t-k \cdot \mathbf{r})}, \mathbf{k}=k \mathbf{e}_{z}$, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}}=-\omega^{2}, \quad \nabla^{2} \mathbf{E}=-k^{2} \mathbf{E}, \\
\nabla \cdot \mathbf{P}=-i \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{P}=-i k P_{z}, \quad \nabla(\nabla \cdot \mathbf{P})=-k^{2} P_{z} \mathbf{e}_{z},
\end{gathered}
$$

and thus

$$
\epsilon_{0}\left(k^{2} c^{2}-\omega^{2}\right) \mathbf{E}=-k^{2} c^{2} P_{z} \mathbf{e}_{z}+\omega^{2} \mathbf{P}
$$

since $\mu_{0} \epsilon_{0}=c^{-2}$. Letting $\chi=\frac{k^{2} c^{2}}{\omega^{2}}-1$, we can write the above as

$$
\epsilon_{0} \chi \mathbf{E}=P_{x} \mathbf{e}_{x}+P_{y} \mathbf{e}_{y}-\chi P_{z} \mathbf{e}_{z},
$$

or

$$
\left(\begin{array}{c}
E_{x} \\
E_{y} \\
E_{z}
\end{array}\right)=\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0} \chi}\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -\chi
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
P_{x} \\
P_{y} \\
P_{z}
\end{array}\right) .
$$

The above two matrix equations combine to give

$$
\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0} \chi} & \frac{i \omega}{N e} B & 0 \\
-\frac{i \omega}{N e} B & \frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0} \chi} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & \frac{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\epsilon_{0} \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}+\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0}}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
P_{x} \\
P_{y} \\
P_{z}
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

\pm i \\

\end{array}\right)

$$

\pm i \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

$$

1056.a.Problem Statement:
Circularly polarized light propagates along the $z$-axis through a fully ionized medium in which a static magnetic field $B$ is also directed along the $z$-axis. The index of refraction for right-hand circularly polarized radiation of angular frequency $\omega$ is

$$
n_{\mathbf{R}}^{2}=1-\frac{4 \pi N e^{2} / m}{\omega^{2}+\frac{e B \omega}{m c}},
$$

where $N$ is the electron density and $e, m$ and $c$ have their usual meaning.

What is the corresponding expression for left-hand circularly polarized light?
1056.a.Solution:
The equation of motion of an electron in the medium is

$$
m \frac{d^{2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}=-e(\mathbf{E}+\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}),
$$

where $\mathbf{r}$ is the displacement of the electron from the original position. The force on the electron due to the magnetic field associated with the traversing light has been omitted as it is smaller than the force due to the associated electric field by a factor $v / c$. With $\mathbf{E}=E_{x} \mathbf{e}_{x}+E_{y} \mathbf{e}_{y}, \mathbf{B}=B \mathbf{e}_{z}$, $\mathbf{r}=x \mathbf{e}_{x}+y \mathbf{e}_{y}+z \mathbf{e}_{z}$, the above becomes

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \ddot{x}=-e E_{x}-e B \dot{y}, \\
&m \ddot{y}=-e E_{y}+e B \dot{x}, \\
&m \ddot{z}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The last equation shows that $\dot{z}=$ constant so that any velocity in the $z$ direction is not associated with the oscillation caused by the traversing light and can hence be neglected. We can also take $z=0$.

For right-hand circularly polarized light, we have

$$
E_{x}=E_{0} e^{i(\omega t-k z)}, \quad E_{y}=i E_{x},
$$

and so

$$
x=x_{0} e^{i(\omega t-k z)}, \quad y=y_{0} e^{i(\omega t-k z)} .
$$

The equation of motion can thus be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&-m \omega^{2} x=-e E_{x}-i \omega e B y, \\
&-m \omega^{2} y=-e E_{y}+i \omega e B x .
\end{aligned}
$$

In terms of the polarization vector $\mathbf{P}=-N e \mathbf{r}$, the above become

$$
\begin{aligned}
-\frac{m \omega^{2}}{N e} P_{x} &=e E_{x}-\frac{i \omega B}{N} P_{y}, \\
-\frac{m \omega^{2}}{N e} P_{y} &=e E_{y}+\frac{i \omega B}{N} P .
\end{aligned}
$$

Maxwell's equation for a source-free isotropic medium,

$$
\nabla+\mathbf{E}=-\dot{\mathbf{B}}, \quad \nabla \times \mathbf{H}=\dot{\mathbf{D}},
$$

with

$$
\mathbf{B}=\mu_{0} \mathbf{H}, \quad \mathbf{D}=\epsilon_{0} \mathbf{E}+\mathbf{P}
$$

give

$$
\mu_{0} \ddot{\mathbf{P}}-\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0}} \nabla(\nabla \cdot \mathbf{P})=\nabla^{2} \mathbf{E}-\frac{1}{c^{2}} \ddot{\mathbf{E}} .
$$

We also have $\nabla \cdot \mathbf{D}=0$, which gives

$$
\nabla \cdot \mathbf{P}=\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0}} \nabla \cdot \mathbf{E}=\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0}} \frac{\partial E_{z}}{\partial z}=0
$$

since $\mathbf{E}$ depends on $z$ only and $E_{z}=0$. This also implies that $P_{z}=0$. Noting that

$$
\nabla^{2} \mathbf{E}=-k^{2} \mathbf{E}, \quad \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}}=-\omega^{2},
$$

we finally have

$$
\mathbf{P}=\chi \mathbf{E},
$$

where

$$
\chi=\epsilon_{0}\left(\frac{c^{2} k^{2}}{\omega^{2}}-1\right) .
$$

The differential equations for $P_{x}, P_{y}$ can now be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left(\frac{\omega^{2}}{N e}+\frac{e}{m \chi}\right) E_{x}-\frac{i \omega B}{N m} E_{y}=0, \\
&\frac{i \omega B}{N m} E_{x}+\left(\frac{\omega^{2}}{N e}+\frac{e}{m \chi}\right) E_{y}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

For nonvanishing solutions, we require that the determinant of the coeffcients of $E_{x}, E_{y}$ be zero. This gives

$$
\left(\frac{\omega^{2}}{N e}+\frac{e}{m \chi}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{\omega B}{N m}\right)^{2}
$$

which has two solutions

$$
\frac{\omega^{2}}{N e}+\frac{e}{m \chi_{\pm}}=\pm \frac{\omega B}{N m} .
$$

The top sign gives $E y=-i E_{x}$, which is the left-hand circularly polarized light. The refraction index $n_{R}$ for the right-hand circularly polarized light is then given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
n_{\mathrm{R}}^{2} &=\frac{\epsilon_{0} E+P}{\epsilon_{0} E}=1+\frac{\chi_{-}}{\epsilon_{0}} \\
&=1-\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega^{2}+\omega \omega_{\mathrm{g}}},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}=\frac{N e^{2}}{m \epsilon_{0}}, \omega_{\mathrm{g}}=\frac{e B}{m}$. Note that in Gaussian units,

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}=\frac{4 \pi N e^{2}}{m}, \quad \omega_{\mathrm{g}}=\frac{e B}{m c},
$$

and the expression for $n_{\mathrm{R}}^{2}$ is identical with that given in the problem.

For the left-hand circularly polarized light,

$$
n_{\mathrm{L}}^{2}=1+\frac{\chi_{+}}{\epsilon_{0}}=1-\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega^{2}-\omega \omega_{\mathrm{g}}} .
$$

1057.b.Problem Statement:
Below are listed some measured properties of $\mathrm{NaCl}$ at room temperature: static dielectric constant $\varepsilon=5.90$, side of unit cell $a=5.6 \AA$, atomic mass of $\mathrm{Na}=23 \mathrm{amu}\left(1 \mathrm{amu}=1.66 \times 10^{-24} \mathrm{~g}\right)$, atomic mass of $\mathrm{Cl}$ $=35.5 \mathrm{amu}$.

For what band of photon wavelengths would you expect $\mathrm{NaCl}$ to reflect incident radiation? (That is, obtain and evaluate expressions for the shortest and longest wavelengths of this band.)
1057.b.Solution:
Fig. $1.33$

$$
\mathbf{P}=\rho_{0} \mathbf{W}=\frac{q^{2}}{2 K V} \mathbf{E}=\epsilon_{0} \chi \mathbf{E}
$$

where $\epsilon_{0}$ is the free-space permittivity and $\chi$ the electric susceptibility related to the relative dielectric constant $\varepsilon$ by $\chi=\varepsilon-1$. The force constant is then

$$
K=\frac{q^{2}}{2 \chi \epsilon_{0} V}=\frac{q^{2}}{2(\varepsilon-1) \epsilon_{0} V} \text {. }
$$

Setting $Q=\frac{\rho_{0}}{\epsilon_{0}} W$, we have from the equation of motion

$$
\ddot{\mathbf{Q}}+\omega_{0}^{2} \mathbf{Q}-\omega_{0}^{2} \chi \mathbf{E}=0
$$

where

$$
\omega_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{2 K}{\mu}}=\sqrt{\frac{q^{2}}{\mu(\varepsilon-1) \epsilon_{0} V}}
$$

is the angular frequency of the optical mode when $k=0$, which is characteristic of the optical mode. To find the interaction of the optical mode with the traversing electromagnetic waves and derive the coupled mode, we have to combine this characteristic equation with Maxwell's equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\nabla \times \mathbf{E}=-\dot{\mathbf{B}} \\
&\nabla \times \mathbf{H}=-\dot{\mathbf{D}}+\mathbf{J}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $\mathrm{B}=\mu_{0} \mathbf{H}, \mathrm{D}=\epsilon_{0} \mathbf{E}, J_{0}=\rho_{0} \dot{\mathbf{W}}=\epsilon_{0} \dot{Q}$ being the current density. Furthermore, as the medium is charge-free (apart from the ions), $\nabla \cdot \mathbf{E}=$ $\frac{1}{\epsilon_{0}} \nabla \cdot D=0$. Hence

$$
\nabla \times(\nabla \times \mathbf{E})=-\nabla^{2} \mathbf{E}=-\mu_{0} \nabla \times \dot{\mathbf{H}}=-\mu_{0} \epsilon_{0}(\ddot{\mathbf{E}}+\ddot{\mathbf{Q}}),
$$

or

$$
\nabla^{2} \mathbf{E}=\frac{1}{c^{2}} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial t^{2}}(\mathbf{E}+\dot{\mathbf{Q}}) .
$$

Taking the direction of propagation of the electromagnetic wave as the $x$ direction, we have

$$
\mathbf{E}=\mathbf{E}_{0} e^{i(k x-\omega t)}, \quad \mathbf{Q}=\mathbf{Q}_{0} e^{i(k x-\omega t)} .
$$

(1) and (2) results in

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right) \mathbf{Q}_{0}=\chi \omega_{0}^{2} \mathbf{E}_{0} \\
k^{2} c^{2} \mathbf{E}_{0}=\omega^{2}\left(\mathbf{E}_{0}+\mathbf{Q}_{0}\right)
\end{array}\right.
$$

which give the dispersion relation of the coupled mode

$$
\frac{c^{2} k^{2}}{\omega^{2}}=\frac{\varepsilon \omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}
$$

It is seen that for $k \rightarrow 0, \omega \rightarrow 0$ or $\omega \rightarrow \sqrt{\varepsilon} \omega_{0}$; for $k \rightarrow \infty, \omega \rightarrow \omega_{0}$ or $\omega \rightarrow \infty$. The relation consists of two branches as shown in Fig. 1.34.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_41580ef03e6631735034g-40.jpg?height=439&width=528&top_left_y=1420&top_left_x=842)

Fig. $1.34$

As shown in Fig. 1.34, in the band between $\omega_{0}$ and $\sqrt{\varepsilon} \omega_{0}$, coupling between the phonons and photons is forbidden and the incident light will be completely reflected. The shortest and longest wavelengths of this band are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda_{\min } &=\frac{2 \pi c}{\sqrt{\varepsilon} \omega_{0}}=\frac{2 \pi c}{q} \sqrt{\epsilon_{0} \mu V\left(1-\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right)} \\
\lambda_{\max } &=\frac{2 \pi c}{\omega_{0}}=\frac{2 \pi c}{q} \sqrt{\epsilon_{0} \mu V(\varepsilon-1)}
\end{aligned}
$$

For $\mathrm{NaCl}, V=\frac{1}{4} a^{3}, \mu=\frac{M_{\mathrm{Na}} m_{\mathrm{Cl}}}{M_{\mathrm{Na}}+m_{\mathrm{Cl}}}, q=e$, with the data given we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda_{\min } &=32.2 \mu \mathrm{m}, \\
\lambda_{\max } &=78.3 \mu \mathrm{m} .
\end{aligned}
$$

1058.a.Problem Statement:
Suppose you are given an alkali halide with $\varepsilon(0)=5.9, \varepsilon(\infty)=2.25$, reflectivity $=0$ at $\lambda=3.06 \mu \mathrm{m}$, and $\varepsilon(\omega)$ real.

Find $\omega_{\mathrm{L}}, \omega_{\mathrm{T}}$.
(Recall that $\omega_{\mathrm{T}}$ is the TO phonon frequency in the absence of any coupling to external fields and defines a pole of $\varepsilon(\omega)$, whereas $\omega_{\mathrm{L}}$ defines a zero of $\left.\varepsilon(\omega).\right)$
1058.a.Solution:
For an ionic crystal, if viscous damping can be neglected, the dielectric constant is real and the relative dielectric constant can be expressed as

$$
\varepsilon(\omega)=\varepsilon(\infty)+\frac{[\varepsilon(0)-\varepsilon(\infty)] \omega_{\mathbf{T}}^{2}}{\omega_{\mathrm{T}}^{2}-\omega^{2}} .
$$

The refractive index of a substance is $n=\sqrt{\varepsilon(\omega)}$ and for normal incidence the reflectivity is

$$
R=\left(\frac{n-1}{n+1}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{\sqrt{\varepsilon(\omega)}-1}{\sqrt{\varepsilon(\omega)+1}}\right)^{2} .
$$

If $R=0$ at $\omega=\omega_{0}$, then $\varepsilon\left(\omega_{0}\right)=1$, or

$$
1=\varepsilon(\infty)+\frac{[\varepsilon(0)-\varepsilon(\infty)] \omega_{\mathbf{T}}^{2}}{\omega_{\mathrm{T}}^{2}-\omega_{0}^{2}},
$$

giving

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{T}}=\left[\frac{\varepsilon(\infty)-1}{\varepsilon(0)-1}\right]^{1 / 2} \omega_{0} .
$$

As $\omega_{0}=\frac{2 \pi c}{\lambda_{0}}=\frac{2 \pi \times 3 \times 10^{8}}{30.6 \times 10^{-6}}=6.16 \times 10^{13} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}, \varepsilon(0)=5.9, \varepsilon(\infty)=2.25$,

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{T}}=\sqrt{\frac{1.25}{4.9}} \times 6.16 \times 10^{13}=3.11 \times 10^{13} \mathrm{~s}^{-1} \text {. }
$$

At $\omega=\omega_{\mathrm{L}}, \varepsilon(\omega)=0$, i.e.,

$$
\varepsilon(\infty)+\frac{[\varepsilon(0)-\varepsilon(\infty)] \omega_{\mathrm{T}}^{2}}{\omega_{\mathrm{T}}^{2}-\omega_{\mathrm{L}}^{2}}=0,
$$

giving the Lyddane-Sachs-Teller relation

$$
\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{L}}^{2}}{\omega_{\mathrm{T}}^{2}}=\frac{\varepsilon(0)}{\varepsilon(\infty)} .
$$

Hence

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{L}}=\left[\frac{\varepsilon(0)}{\varepsilon(\infty)}\right]^{1 / 2} \omega_{\mathrm{T}}=5.04 \times 10^{13} \mathrm{~s}^{-1} .
$$

1062.b.Problem Statement:
Evaluate $g\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}\right)$ for a free electron gas in which electron-ion interactions are also ignored.
(A derivation is required here; do not simply state the standard result.)
1062.b.Solution:
The energy of an electron in a magnetic field of flux density $\mathbf{B}$ is

$$
\varepsilon(k)-\boldsymbol{\mu} \cdot \mathbf{B}=\varepsilon(k) \mp \mu_{\mathrm{B}} B,
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\mu}$ is the magnetic dipole moment due to the spin of the electron, $\varepsilon(k)$ denotes electron energy in the absence of the magnetic field, and the $\pm$ signs correspond to dipole moments parallel and antiparallel to the field respectively. Let $g(\varepsilon)$ be density of states of independent electrons per unit volume taking spin into account. Setting $\varepsilon=\varepsilon(k)$, we have for the total number of electrons with parallel and antiparallel spins respectively

$$
\begin{aligned}
&N_{+}=V \int_{0}^{\varepsilon_{+}(k)_{\max }} \frac{1}{2} g(\varepsilon) d \varepsilon, \\
&N_{-}=V \int_{0}^{\varepsilon_{-}(k)_{\max }} \frac{1}{2} g(\varepsilon) d \varepsilon .
\end{aligned}
$$

At $T=0, \varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}=\varepsilon_{+}(k)_{\max }-\mu_{\mathrm{B}} B=\varepsilon_{-}(k)_{\max }+\mu_{\mathrm{B}} B$, where $\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}$ is the Fermi energy, and thus 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&N_{+}=V \int_{0}^{\varepsilon_{F}+\mu_{B} B} \frac{1}{2} g(\varepsilon) d \varepsilon \\
&N_{-}=V \int_{0}^{\varepsilon_{F}-\mu_{B} B} \frac{1}{2} g(\varepsilon) d \varepsilon .
\end{aligned}
$$

If $\mu_{\mathrm{B}} B \gg \varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}$, we can take $\epsilon \approx \epsilon_{\mathrm{F}}$ under the integral sign and find

$$
N_{+}-N_{-} \approx \frac{1}{2} V \cdot 2 \mu_{\mathrm{B}} B \cdot g\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}\right)=V \mu_{\mathrm{B}} B g\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}\right) .
$$

The magnetization $M$ is by definition

$$
M=\frac{1}{V}\left(N_{+}-N_{-}\right) \mu_{\mathrm{B}}=\mu_{\mathrm{B}}^{2} g\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}\right) B .
$$

The spin susceptibility is therefore

$$
\chi=\frac{M}{H}=\frac{\mu_{0} M}{B}=\mu_{0} \mu_{\mathrm{B}}^{2} g\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}\right),
$$

or, in Gaussian units where $\mu_{0}=1$,

$$
\chi=\mu_{\mathrm{B}}^{2} g\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{F}}\right),
$$

provided that $B$ is small.

For a free electron

$$
\varepsilon=\frac{\hbar^{2} k^{2}}{2 m}, \quad \frac{d k}{d \varepsilon}=\frac{m}{\hbar^{2} k} .
$$

The number of electron states per unit volume in the energy range $\varepsilon, \varepsilon+d \varepsilon$ corresponds to the density of states in $k$-space in a spherical shell of radius $k$ and thickness $d k$ :

$$
\rho(\varepsilon) d \varepsilon=2 \times \frac{4 \pi k^{2} d k}{(2 \pi)^{3}}=\frac{k^{2}}{\pi^{2}} \frac{d k}{d \varepsilon} d \varepsilon,
$$

where the factor 2 is due to the fact that each energy state comprises two spin states. Hence

$$
\rho(\varepsilon)=\frac{m k}{\pi^{2} \hbar^{2}}=\frac{1}{2 \pi^{2}}\left(\frac{2 m}{\hbar^{2}}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}} \varepsilon^{\frac{1}{2}} .
$$
1062.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

1064.a.Problem Statement:
Consider an ideal gas of stable vector mesons (massive particles with spin 1) with magnetic moment $\mu$.

Compute the paramagnetic susceptibility per unit volume in a weak magnetic field.
1064.a.Solution:
For an ideal gas, in which the particles are non-interacting, the partition function of a single particle is

$$
z_{1}=e^{-\beta \varepsilon}+1+e^{\beta \varepsilon},
$$

where $\varepsilon=\mu B, \beta=\frac{1}{k_{\mathrm{B}} T}$. The probabilities for its magnetic moment to be parallel, perpendicular and antiparallel to the magnetic field $\mathbf{B}$ are respectively .

$$
P_{+}=\frac{e^{\beta \varepsilon}}{z_{1}}, \quad P_{0}=\frac{1}{z_{1}}, \quad P_{-}=\frac{e^{-\beta \varepsilon}}{z_{1}} .
$$

Hence the mean magnetic moment along the direction of the field per particle is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\mu} &=\mu\left(P_{+}-P_{-}\right)=\mu \cdot \frac{e^{\beta \varepsilon}-e^{-\beta \varepsilon}}{z_{1}} \\
&=\frac{2 \mu \sinh (\beta \varepsilon)}{2 \cosh (\beta \varepsilon)+1} .
\end{aligned}
$$

If $n$ is the number of particles per unit volume of the gas, the paramagnetic magnetization is

$$
M=n \bar{\mu}=\frac{2 n \mu \sinh (\beta \varepsilon)}{2 \cosh (\beta \varepsilon)+1} .
$$

In a weak magnetic field, $\mu B \ll k_{\mathrm{B}} T$, or $\beta \varepsilon \ll 1, \sinh (\beta \varepsilon) \approx \beta \varepsilon, \cosh (\beta \varepsilon) \approx$ 1 , and so

$$
M=\frac{2 n \mu \beta \varepsilon}{3}=\frac{2 n \mu^{2} B}{3 k_{\mathrm{B}} T} .
$$

Hence the paramagnetic susceptibility is

$$
\chi=\frac{M}{H}=\frac{\mu_{0} M}{B}=\frac{2 n \mu_{0} \mu^{2}}{3 k_{\mathrm{B}} T} .
$$

1065.Problem Statement: What is the typical saturation value for the density of magnetization of iron/steel (state units)? From this value and the values of other specified quantities, and stated assumptions about the nature of ferromagnetism, estimate the intrinsic-spin magnetic moment of the electron.
1065.Solution:
In an applied magnetic field, the magnetization of iron increases with the intensity of the field. When the field increases to a certain value, the magnetization will not increase further but reach a saturation value $M_{\mathbf{s}}$, at which time, according to the theory of ferromagnetism, all magnetic moments due to electron spin are aligned along the direction of the applied magnetic field. Let the number density of electrons in a ferromagnetic material be $n$ and the magnetic moment due to the spin of an electron be $\mu$, then

$$
M_{\mathrm{s}}=n \mu .
$$

The saturation magnetization of iron is typically $M_{\mathrm{s}}=10^{6} \mathrm{Am}^{-1}$, and as $n=3 \times 10^{28} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$, the intrinsic-spin magnetic moment of an electron is $\mu=\frac{M_{\mathrm{s}}}{n} \approx 3 \times 10^{-23} \mathrm{Am}^{2}$.

1071.Problem Statement:
When a metal enters the superconducting state it becomes more ordered and its free energy decreases.

What is the nature of the new ordering? Consider a superconducting ring carrying a circulating persistent current. Suppose that at some instant thermal fluctuations cause a small decrease in this current. In terms of your answer above, explain why the system will restore the current to its previous value.

Explain why there is an energy gap when one tries to add energy to a superconductor by shining light on it, but not when one adds energy by applying a dc current.
1071.Solution:
When a metal enters the superconducting state, electrons lying deep inside the Fermi sphere remain normal electrons, but electrons very near the Fermi surface couple to form Cooper pairs. These are the superconducting electrons and are condensed into the lowest energy state, which does not contribute to entropy and is a highly ordered state. Thus when a metal enters the superconducting state it becomes ordered and its free energy decreases.

At some instant, some Cooper pairs may be destroyed by thermal fluctuations. The density of superconducting electrons then decreases, which causes a small decrease in the current. At that time, the ordering of the system becomes less and the free energy increases. But the energy of the system must be conserved, so some other electrons near the Fermi surface inevitably couple to form superconducting electrons, and their density increases. The system will thus restore the current to its previous value. There is an energy gap $\Delta$ between the superconducting ground state and the lowest excited state. When shining light on a superconductor, the latter absorbs light appreciably only if the energy of the photon is larger than or equal to $\Delta$. This means that there is an energy gap when one tries to add energy to a superconductor by shining light on it. On the other hand, when a dc current is applied, a Cooper pair moves as a whole and does not have to overcome the energy gap.

1076.Problem Statement:
A ring is made of $1 \mathrm{~mm}$ diameter lead wire formed into a circle of $10 \mathrm{~cm}$ diameter as shown in Fig. 1.45. The ring is in the superconducting state and has a 100 A current flowing in it. It is observed that there is no detectable change in current for a period of 1 year. If the detector is sensitive to a change in current of a little as $1 \mu \mathrm{A}$, calculate the experimental upper limit for the resistivity of lead in the superconducting state.

Note: An answer within a factor of three will suffice.

(Chicago )

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_41580ef03e6631735034g-72.jpg?height=282&width=588&top_left_y=1789&top_left_x=823)

Fig. $1.45$
1076.Solution:
Let $\rho$ be the resistivity of lead. Then the resistance of the ring is $R=\rho \frac{l}{S}$, where $l=2 \pi r, S$ is the cross-sectional area of the lead wire. The ring may be considered as an RL circuit, so that 

$$
-L \frac{d I}{d t}=I R,
$$

or

$$
I(t)=I(0) e^{-R t / L},
$$

i.e.

$$
R=\frac{L}{t} \ln \frac{I(0)}{I(t)} .
$$

The self-inductance $L$ is given by the flux linkage $\Phi$ and the current $I$ by $L=\Phi / I$, thus

$$
I(0)=100 \mathrm{~A}, \quad I(t)=100-10^{-6} \mathrm{~A} .
$$

The magnetic field distribution in the ring is somewhat complicated, but for a rough estimate we can approximate the magnetic field inside the ring by a uniform field equal in magnitude to that at the center of the ring. Thus

$$
\Phi=\pi r^{2} B=\pi r^{2} \cdot \frac{\mu_{0} I}{2 r}=\frac{1}{2} \pi \mu_{0} r I
$$

and

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} \pi \mu_{0} r .
$$

As $I(t) \approx I(0), \frac{R t}{L} \ll 1$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta I &=I(0)-I(t) \approx \frac{I_{0} R t}{L}, \\
\ln \frac{I(0)}{I(t)} &=\ln \left[1+\frac{\Delta I}{I(t)}\right] \approx \frac{\Delta I}{I(0)} \approx 10^{-8}, \\
R & \approx \frac{\pi \mu_{0} r}{2 t}\left[\frac{\Delta I}{I(0)}\right]=\frac{\pi}{2} \times \frac{4 \pi \times 10^{-7} \times 5 \times 10^{-2}}{365 \times 24 \times 3600} \times 10^{-8} \\
&=3.13 \times 10^{-23} \Omega .
\end{aligned}
$$

This gives

$$
\rho=\frac{S R}{2 \pi r}=\frac{\pi \times\left(0.5 \times 10^{-3}\right)^{2} \times 3.13 \times 10^{-23}}{2 \pi \times 5 \times 10^{-2}}=7.8 \times 10^{-29} \Omega \mathrm{m} .
$$

1077.Problem Statement:
A currently important technique for precisely measuring the lifetimes of states of multiply ionized atoms consists of exciting a beam of the desired ions with a laser tuned to a resonance wavelength of the ion under study, and measuring the emission intensity from the ion beam as a function of down- stream distance. When a particular ion beam with a resonance wavelength at $4885 \AA$ is excited with a $4880 \AA$ argon-ion laser output, the intensity is found to drop by a factor of two, $10 \mathrm{~mm}$ down-stream from the excitation point. If ion beam velocity is $v / c=5 \times 10^{-3}$, calculate the angle the laser beam must make with the normal to the ion beam to achieve resonance and the lifetime of the excited state of the ion.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_41580ef03e6631735034g-74.jpg?height=301&width=417&top_left_y=1302&top_left_x=865)

Fig. $1.46$
1077.Solution:
Take two coordinate frames $\Sigma, \Sigma^{\prime} . \Sigma$ is the laboratory frame in which the laser source $L$ is at rest and the ions move with velocity $\beta c$ along the $x$-axis as shown in Fig. 1.46. $\Sigma^{\prime}$ is the rest frame of an ion in the beam and moves with velocity $\beta c$ relative to $\Sigma$ along the $x$ direction. Consider the transformation of the 4 -vector $\left(\mathbf{k}, \frac{\omega}{c}\right)$. We have

$$
\frac{\omega^{\prime}}{c}=\gamma\left(\frac{\omega}{c}-\beta k \sin \theta\right),
$$

where $\gamma=\left(1-\beta^{2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}, k=\frac{\omega}{c}$. Hence 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sin \theta &=\frac{1}{\beta}\left(1-\frac{\lambda}{\lambda^{\prime}} \sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}\right) \\
& \approx \frac{1}{\beta}\left[1-\frac{\lambda}{\lambda^{\prime}}\left(1-\frac{\beta^{2}}{2}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

With $\lambda=4885 \AA, \lambda^{\prime}=4880 \AA, \beta=5 \times 10^{-3}$, we find

$$
\sin \theta=0.2074, \quad \text { or } \quad \theta=11.97^{\circ} \text {. }
$$

As the excited ions move with velocity $\beta c$, on account of time dilation the laboratory lifetime of an ion is $\gamma \tau$, where $\tau$ is the proper lifetime. Hence the excited ion beam will decay according to

$$
I=I_{0} \exp \left(-\frac{t}{\gamma \tau}\right)
$$

giving

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tau &=\frac{t}{\gamma \ln \left(\frac{I_{0}}{I}\right)}=\frac{x}{\gamma \beta c \ln \left(\frac{I_{0}}{I}\right)} \\
& \approx\left(1-\frac{\beta^{2}}{2}\right) \frac{x}{\beta c \ln \left(\frac{I_{0}}{I}\right)}=9.6 \times 10^{-9} \mathrm{~s} .
\end{aligned}
$$

1079.Problem Statement: Describe briefly the basic parts and principle of operation of a hotcathode ionization gauge for measuring pressure in a vacuum system. State approximately the high and low pressure limits of the gauge and the factors which determine these limits.
1079.Solution:
A hot-cathode ionization gauge consists of a cathode F, an accelerator A and a collector C, as shown in Fig. $1.49$ together with a typical circuit for its operation.

The cathode filament, heated by an electric current, emits electrons which move toward the accelerator A maintained at a positive potential. Some of the electrons are absorbed by A while others pass through the gaps between the grids of the accelerator toward the collector $\mathrm{C}$, kept at a negative potential, which repulses the electrons as they approach C. Thus the electrons oscillate to and fro between $\mathrm{C}$ and $\mathrm{A}$ until they are absorbed by A. During such oscillations the electron collide frequently with the gas molecules in the tube, giving rise to positive ions and electrons. The positive 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_11_07_41580ef03e6631735034g-79.jpg?height=621&width=575&top_left_y=435&top_left_x=794)

Fig. $1.49$

ions are collected by the collector $\mathrm{C}$ to give an ionic current $i_{+}$, and the electrons are collected by the accelerator to give an electric current $i_{\mathrm{e}}$. Theory shows that the pressure $p$ in the tube can be expressed as

$$
p=K \frac{i_{+}}{i_{\mathrm{e}}},
$$

where $K$ is a constant. If $i_{\mathrm{e}}$ is kept constant, then

$$
p=K_{1} i_{+},
$$

which enables one to determine the pressure in a vacuum system by measuring the ionic current $i_{+}$.

The high pressure limit of the ionization gauge is about $10^{-3}$ torr. When $p>10^{-3}$ torr, the filament is easily burnt out; furthermore, $i_{+}$ does not increase with $p$, as due to the chemical cleaning of the hot filament it behaves as an absorber of gas. The low pressure limit is about $10^{-7}$ torr, below which the current collected by the collector is mainly the photoemission current; only a small fraction of it is the ionic current with the result that $p$ does not vary linearly with $i_{+}$.

2003.Problem Statement: A light beam is propagating through a block of glass with index of refraction $n$. If the glass is moving at constant velocity $v$ in the same direction as the beam, what is the velocity of light in the block as measured by an observer in the laboratory?
2003.Solution:
In a reference frame fixed on the block of glass, the velocity of light in the glass is

$$
u^{\prime}=\frac{c}{n} .
$$

This frame moves with velocity $v$ relative to the laboratory frame. Hence the equation for transformation of velocity gives the velocity in the laboratory frame as

$$
u=\frac{u^{\prime}+v}{1+\frac{u^{\prime} v}{c^{2}}}=\frac{\frac{c}{n}+v}{1+\frac{(c / n) v}{c^{2}}}=\frac{c+n v}{n+\frac{v}{c}}
$$

2004.a.Problem Statement:
This problem is to be analyzed according to the doctrines of special relativity.

An observer A at rest relative to fixed distant stars sees an isotropic distribution of stars in a finite galaxy: the number of stars seen within an element of solid angle $d \Omega$ is $P d \Omega=\frac{N}{4 \pi} d \Omega$, where $N$ is the total number of stars that A can see.

Another observer B moves uniformly along the $z$-axis relative to $\mathrm{A}$ with a large velocity $v=\beta c$. Let $\theta$ and $\varphi$ be respectively the polar (with respect to the $z$-axis) and azimuthal angles in the inertial frame of $\mathrm{B}$, and let $P^{\prime}\left(\theta^{\prime}, \varphi^{\prime}\right) d \Omega^{\prime}$ be the number of stars in the element $d \Omega^{\prime}=\sin \theta^{\prime} d \theta^{\prime} d \varphi^{\prime}$ seen by B.

Compute $P^{\prime}$ as a function of $\theta^{\prime}, \varphi^{\prime}$, assuming that every star seen by $\mathrm{A}$ can be seen by $\mathrm{B}$.
2004.a.Solution:
Consider transformation of the propagation four-vector $k^{\alpha}=\left(\mathbf{k}, \frac{\omega}{c}\right)$ of the light wave from a star, where $|\mathbf{k}| \equiv k=\frac{\omega}{c}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& k^{\prime} \cos \theta^{\prime}=\gamma\left(k \cos \theta-\frac{\omega}{c} \beta\right)=\gamma k(\cos \theta-\beta) \text {, } \\
& k^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\frac{\omega}{c}-k \beta \cos \theta\right)=\gamma k(1-\beta \cos \theta) .
\end{aligned}
$$

These combine to give

$$
\cos \theta^{\prime}=\frac{\cos \theta-\beta}{1-\beta \cos \theta},
$$

or

$$
1+\beta \cos \theta^{\prime}=\frac{1-\beta^{2}}{1-\beta \cos \theta} .
$$

Differentiating we have

$$
\frac{d \cos \theta^{\prime}}{d \cos \theta}=\frac{1-\beta^{2}}{(1-\beta \cos \theta)^{2}} .
$$

In spherical coordinates

$$
d \Omega=\frac{r d \theta \cdot r \sin \theta d \varphi}{r^{2}}=-d \cos \theta \cdot d \varphi .
$$

Thus

$$
d \Omega^{\prime}=\frac{d \cos \theta^{\prime}}{d \cos \theta} d \Omega=\frac{\left(1-\beta^{2}\right)}{(1-\beta \cos \theta)^{2}} d \Omega,
$$

or, for the inverse transformation,

$$
d \Omega=\frac{\left(1-\beta^{2}\right)}{\left(1+\beta \cos \theta^{\prime}\right)^{2}} d \Omega^{\prime}
$$

As the same stars are seen by both $A$ and $B$,

$$
P^{\prime}\left(\theta^{\prime}, \varphi^{\prime}\right) d \Omega^{\prime}=P(\theta, \varphi) d \Omega,
$$

and so

$$
P^{\prime}\left(\theta^{\prime}, \varphi^{\prime}\right)=\frac{N}{4 \pi} \frac{d \Omega}{d \Omega^{\prime}}=\frac{N}{4 \pi} \frac{1-\beta^{2}}{\left(1+\beta \cos \theta^{\prime}\right)^{2}} .
$$
2004.a.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

2007.a.Problem Statement:
Consider the collision of $n$ bodies in a Lorentz frame $S$. The bodies are small enough to be adequately characterized by their rest masses and velocities, and they collide simultaneously at the same point. Assume the velocities and rest masses to be $\mathbf{v}_{\alpha}$ and $m_{\alpha}(\alpha=1, \ldots, n)$ before collision, and $\mathbf{v}_{\alpha}^{\prime}$ and $m_{\alpha}^{\prime}(\alpha=1, \ldots, n)$ after collision.
(All $m_{\alpha}$ and $m_{\alpha}^{\prime}$ are positive.)

For given $\mathbf{v}_{\alpha}$ and $m_{\alpha}$ call a collision maximally inelastic in $S$ if after the collision the sum of kinetic energies of all bodies has the smallest value compatible with energy and momentum conservation.
(The kinetic energy of a body is $m_{\alpha} c^{2}\left[\left(1-\frac{v_{\alpha}^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)^{-1 / 2}-1\right]$.)

Find $v_{\alpha}^{\prime}$ and $m_{\alpha}^{\prime}$ - to the extent that they are determinate - for a maximally inelastic collision.
2007.a.Solution:
The total kinetic energy after the collision is

$$
T=\sum\left(m_{\alpha}^{\prime} \gamma_{\alpha}^{\prime} c^{2}-m_{\alpha}^{\prime} c^{2}\right)
$$

with $\gamma_{\alpha}^{\prime}=\left(1-\frac{v_{\alpha}^{\prime}}{c^{2}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}$. As there is no external force acting on the system, energy is conserved:

$$
\sum m_{\alpha}^{\prime} \gamma_{\alpha}^{\prime} c^{2}=\sum m_{\alpha} \gamma_{\alpha} c^{2}
$$

Thus

$$
T=\sum\left(m_{\alpha} \gamma_{\alpha} c^{2}-m_{\alpha}^{\prime} c^{2}\right) .
$$

For $T$ to be minimum, we require $\sum m_{\alpha}^{\prime}$ to be a maximum compatible with conservation of energy and momentum.

Consider the collision in the center of mass frame $S_{\mathrm{cm}}$, which is given by its velocity relative to $S$ :

$$
\mathbf{u}=\frac{\sum m_{\alpha} \gamma_{\alpha} \mathbf{v}_{\alpha}}{\sum m_{\alpha} \gamma_{\alpha}} .
$$

Denoting all quantities in this frame by a bar we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{T} &=\sum\left(m_{\alpha} \bar{\gamma}_{\alpha}^{\prime} c^{2}-m_{\alpha}^{\prime} c^{2}\right) \\
&=\sum\left(m_{\alpha} \bar{\gamma}_{\alpha} c^{2}-m_{\alpha}^{\prime} c^{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $\bar{T} \geq 0, \sum m_{\alpha}^{\prime} \leq \sum m_{\alpha} \bar{\gamma}_{\alpha}$. Hence $\sum m_{\alpha}^{\prime}$ has the maximum value $\sum m_{\alpha} \bar{\gamma}_{\alpha}$

For a system the quantity $E^{2}-P^{2} c^{2}$ is Lorentz invariant. Thus

$$
\left(\sum m_{\alpha} \gamma_{\alpha} c^{2}\right)^{2}-\left(\sum m_{\alpha} \gamma_{\alpha} \mathbf{v}_{\alpha}\right)^{2} c^{2}=\left(\sum m_{\alpha} \bar{\gamma}_{\alpha} c^{2}\right)^{2}
$$

since $\bar{P}=0$ in $S_{\mathrm{cm}}$, i.e.,

$$
\left(\sum m_{\alpha} \gamma_{\alpha}\right)^{2}-\left(\sum m_{\alpha} \gamma_{\alpha}\right)^{2} \frac{u^{2}}{c^{2}}=\left(\sum m_{\alpha} \bar{\gamma}_{\alpha}\right)^{2}
$$

or

$$
\sum m_{\alpha} \bar{\gamma}_{\alpha}=\left(1-\frac{u^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \sum m_{\alpha} \gamma_{\alpha} .
$$

Therefore $\sum m_{\alpha}^{\prime}$ has the maximum value

$$
\left(1-\frac{u^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \sum m_{\alpha} \gamma_{\alpha}
$$

which determines $\sum m_{\alpha}^{\prime}$ for a maximally inelastic collision. Momentum conservation

$$
\sum m_{\alpha}^{\prime} \gamma_{\alpha}^{\prime} \mathbf{v}_{\alpha}^{\prime}=\sum m_{\alpha} \gamma_{\alpha} \mathbf{v}_{\alpha}=\mathbf{u} \sum m_{\alpha} \gamma_{\alpha}
$$

determines the collective velocity $\mathbf{u}$, which is the same before and after the collision.

2008.a.Problem Statement:
What is the form of the "global extension" of Newton's first law of motion in general relativity?

Identify all terms in the generalized equation of motion.
2008.a.Solution:
In special relativity, a particle subject to no force will have a constant four-velocity. That is, $\frac{d u^{\alpha}}{d \tau}=0$. This is exactly Newton's first law or law of inertia. In the general covariant form this becomes $\frac{D u^{\alpha}}{D \tau}=0$, or

$$
\frac{d u^{\alpha}}{d \tau}+\Gamma_{\mu \nu}^{\alpha} \frac{d x^{\mu}}{d \tau} \frac{d x^{\nu}}{d \tau}=0 .
$$

On the left-hand side, the first term denotes the four-acceleration of the particle, the second term represents the action of a gravitational field of intensity $\Gamma_{\mu \nu}^{\alpha}$.

2010.a.Problem Statement:
The Schwarzschild metric describing the space-time outside a spherical mass $M$ is given by

$$
d s^{2}=-\left(1-\frac{2 G M}{c^{2} r}\right) c^{2} d t^{2}+\left(1-\frac{2 G M}{c^{2} r}\right)^{-1} d r^{2}+r^{2}\left(d \theta^{2}+\sin ^{2} \theta d \varphi^{2}\right) .
$$

Find the radius at which a photon can describe a circular orbit.
2010.a.Solution:
Use a coordinate frame with origin at the center of the spherical mass and let

$$
x^{0}=c t, \quad x^{1}=r, \quad x^{2}=\theta, \quad x^{3}=\varphi .
$$

Then the Schwarzschild metric tensor has components

$$
\begin{aligned}
&g_{00}=-\left(1-\frac{k}{r}\right), \quad g_{11}=\left(1-\frac{k}{r}\right)^{-1}, \\
&g_{22}=r^{2}, \quad g_{33}=r^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta \\
&g_{\mu \nu}=0 \text { for } \mu \neq \nu,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $k=\frac{2 G M}{c^{2}}$. The world-line of the photon is a null geodesic given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d}{d s}\left(g_{\alpha \beta} \frac{d x^{\beta}}{d s}\right) &=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\partial g_{\mu \lambda}}{\partial x^{\alpha}} \frac{d x^{\mu}}{d s} \frac{d x^{\lambda}}{d s}, \\
g_{\mu \nu} \frac{d x^{\mu}}{d s} \frac{d x^{\nu}}{d s} &=0,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $s$ is some independent variable. As the mass is spherically symmetric, we can choose coordinates such that the orbit of the photon is in the plane $\theta=\frac{\pi}{2}$

Since $g_{\mu \nu}$ do not depend on $x^{3}$ explicitly, we have

$$
g_{3 \beta} \frac{d x^{\beta}}{d s}=g_{33} \frac{d x^{3}}{d s}=r^{2} \frac{d \varphi}{d s}=h, \quad \text { a constant. }
$$

They also do not depend on $x^{0}$ explicitly, so

$$
g_{0 \beta} \frac{d x^{\beta}}{d s}=g_{00} \frac{d x^{0}}{d s}=-c\left(1-\frac{k}{r}\right) \frac{d t}{d s}=b, \quad \text { a constant. }
$$

We also have

$$
\begin{aligned}
g_{\mu \nu} \frac{d x^{\mu}}{d s} \frac{d x^{\nu}}{d s} &=g_{00}\left(\frac{d x^{0}}{d s}\right)^{2}+g_{11}\left(\frac{d x^{1}}{d s}\right)^{2}+g_{33}\left(\frac{d x^{3}}{d s}\right)^{2} \\
&=-c^{2}\left(1-\frac{k}{r}\right)\left(\frac{d t}{d s}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{\left(1-\frac{k}{r}\right)}\left(\frac{d r}{d s}\right)^{2}+r^{2}\left(\frac{d \varphi}{d s}\right)^{2}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\left(\frac{d r}{d s}\right)^{2}+\left(1-\frac{k}{r}\right) \frac{h^{2}}{r^{2}}-b^{2}=0 .
$$

Letting $\frac{1}{r}=u$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{d u}{d \varphi}=-\frac{1}{r^{2}} \frac{d r}{d \varphi}, \\
&\frac{d r}{d s}=\frac{d r}{d \varphi} \frac{d \varphi}{d s}=\frac{h}{r^{2}} \frac{d r}{d \varphi}=-h \frac{d u}{d \varphi},
\end{aligned}
$$

and Eq.
(4) becomes

$$
h^{2}\left(\frac{d u}{d \varphi}\right)^{2}+(1-k u) h^{2} u^{2}-b^{2}=0 .
$$

Differentiating both sides with respect to $\varphi$, we obtain

$$
\frac{d^{2} u}{d \varphi^{2}}+u-\frac{3 k u^{2}}{2}=0,
$$

i.e.,

$$
\frac{d^{2} u}{d \varphi^{2}}+u-\frac{3 G M}{c^{2}} u^{2}=0 .
$$

For the orbit to be circular, $u=\frac{1}{r}=$ constant. The last equation then gives

$$
r=\frac{3 G M}{c^{2}} .
$$

for the radius of the circular orbit.

2011.b.Problem Statement:
What is the physical significance of
(1) time-like geodesics?
(2) null geodesics?
2011.b.Solution:
The geodesic equation is

$$
\frac{d^{2} x^{\mu}}{d s^{2}}+\Gamma_{\alpha \beta}^{\mu} \frac{d x^{\alpha}}{d s} \frac{d x^{\beta}}{d s}=0 .
$$

(1) Time-like geodesics are those along which the time order of two events cannot be changed by a coordinate transformation.

(2) Null geodesics are paths of light rays or photon in a space-time and are characterized by $d s=0$, or

$$
g_{\mu \nu} \frac{d x^{\mu}}{d s} \frac{d x^{\nu}}{d s}=0 .
$$

The parameter $s$ in the equation is to be considered as an unspecified independent variable.
2011.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

2011.c.Problem Statement:
With a certain choice of coordinate variables $\rho, \theta, \varphi, \psi$ a solution of Einstein's equations has the metric

$$
d s^{2}=-\frac{1}{U(\rho)} d \rho^{2}+4 U(\rho) l^{2}(d \psi+\cos \theta d \varphi)^{2}+\left(\rho^{2}+l^{2}\right)\left(d \theta^{2}+\sin ^{2} \theta d \varphi^{2}\right)
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\infty \leq \rho \leq \infty \text {, } \\
& 0 \leq \theta \leq \pi \text {, } \\
& 0 \leq \varphi \leq 2 \pi \text {, } \\
& 0 \leq \psi \leq 4 \pi \text {, }
\end{aligned}
$$

$\theta, \varphi$, and $\psi$ are cyclic coordinates, and

$$
U(\rho)=-1+\frac{2\left(m \rho+l^{2}\right)}{\rho^{2}+l^{2}},
$$

where $m$ and $l$ are constant parameters.

(1) Find the equations which describe geodesics in the plane $\varphi=0$, $\theta=\frac{\pi}{2}$.

(2) Solving for null geodesic equations in the plane of case (1), show that there are null geodesics which lie in the surface $\varphi=0, \theta=\frac{\pi}{2}$, $\rho=m+\sqrt{m^{2}+l^{2}}$. In a few words, what is it that is physically interesting about these null geodesics?

Information: The Christoffel symbols are defined by $\Gamma_{\beta \nu}^{\alpha}=\frac{1}{2} g^{\alpha \delta}\left(\partial_{\beta} g_{\delta \nu}-\partial_{\delta} g_{\beta \nu}+\partial_{\nu} g_{\delta \beta}\right)$.
2011.c.Solution:
The geodesic equation is

$$
\frac{d^{2} x^{\mu}}{d s^{2}}+\Gamma_{\alpha \beta}^{\mu} \frac{d x^{\alpha}}{d s} \frac{d x^{\beta}}{d s}=0 .
$$

(1) Time-like geodesics are those along which the time order of two events cannot be changed by a coordinate transformation.

(2) Null geodesics are paths of light rays or photon in a space-time and are characterized by $d s=0$, or

$$
g_{\mu \nu} \frac{d x^{\mu}}{d s} \frac{d x^{\nu}}{d s}=0 .
$$

The parameter $s$ in the equation is to be considered as an unspecified independent variable.(1) Let

$$
x^{0}=\rho, \quad x^{1}=\psi, \quad x^{2}=\theta, \quad x^{3}=\varphi .
$$

The metric tensor has nonzero components

$$
\begin{aligned}
&g_{00}=-\frac{1}{U} \quad g_{11}=4 U l^{2}, \quad g_{22}=\rho^{2}+l^{2}, \\
&g_{33}=4 U l^{2} \cos ^{2} \theta+\left(\rho^{2}+l^{2}\right) \sin ^{2} \theta \\
&g_{23}=g_{32}=4 U l^{2} \cos \theta,
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
U=-1+\frac{2\left(m \rho+l^{2}\right)}{\rho^{2}+l^{2}} .
$$

It is more convenient to use an alternative form of the geodesic equation:

$$
\frac{d}{d s}\left(g_{\mu \nu} \frac{d x^{\nu}}{d s}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\partial g_{\alpha \beta}}{\partial x^{\mu}} \frac{d x^{\alpha}}{d s} \frac{d x^{\beta}}{d s} .
$$

As all the $g_{\mu \nu}$ do not depend on $x^{1}$ explicitly and $g_{1 \nu}=0$ for $\nu \neq 1$, the above gives the first integral

$$
g_{11} \frac{d \psi}{d s}=k, \quad \text { a constant. }
$$

Introduce the local proper time $\tau$ defined by $-d \tau^{2}=d s^{2}$ and interpret $\psi$ $(-\infty \leq \psi \leq \infty)$ as the coordinate time $\tau$. The metric gives

$$
-d \tau^{2}=d s^{2}=g_{11} d \psi^{2} .
$$

$\rho$ is interpreted as radial distance $(0 \leq \rho \leq \infty)$. Let $\rho \rightarrow \infty$, then as $U \rightarrow-1, g_{11} \rightarrow-4 l^{2}$, we find $k^{2}=\left(g_{11} \frac{d \psi}{d s}\right)^{2}=g_{11}(\infty)=-4 l^{2}$. If the geodesic is confined to the plane $\varphi=0, \theta=\frac{\pi}{2}$, then $d \varphi=d \theta=0$ and the metric gives

$$
g_{00}\left(\frac{d \rho}{d s}\right)^{2}+g_{11}\left(\frac{d \psi}{d s}\right)^{2}=1,
$$

or

$$
\frac{d \rho}{d s}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{g_{00}}\left(1-\frac{k^{2}}{g_{11}}\right)}=\sqrt{-U\left(1+\frac{4 l^{2}}{4 U l^{2}}\right)}=\sqrt{-1-U(\rho)}
$$

for the geodesic.

(2) For a null geodesic,

$$
g_{\mu \nu} \frac{d x^{\mu}}{d s} \frac{d x^{\nu}}{d s}=0
$$

where $s$ is some unspecified independent variable. For a geodesic confined to the plane $\varphi=0, \theta=\frac{\pi}{2}$, we have

$$
\frac{d \varphi}{d s}=\frac{d \theta}{d s}=0,
$$

and thus

$$
g_{00}\left(\frac{d \rho}{d s}\right)^{2}+g_{11}\left(\frac{d \psi}{d s}\right)^{2}=0
$$

or

$$
\frac{d \rho}{d \psi}=\sqrt{-\frac{g_{11}}{g_{00}}}=2 U l .
$$

$\rho=$ constant, $U=0$ is obviously a solution of this equation. This corresponds to

$$
\rho^{2}+l^{2}=2 m \rho+2 l^{2},
$$

or, taking the positive root,

$$
\rho=m+\sqrt{m^{2}+l^{2}} .
$$

Hence there are null geodesics lying in the surface $\varphi=0, \theta=\frac{\pi}{2}, \rho=$ $m+\sqrt{m^{2}+l^{2}}$.

This result is physically interesting as it indicates that light can propagate along the surface of a sphere of radius $\rho=m+\sqrt{m^{2}+l^{2}}$, but not outside this sphere.
2011.c.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

2013.b.Problem Statement:
Sketch the derivation of the Einstein equations, starting from the assumption that the laws of gravitation take the tensor form $K_{\mu 
u}=8 \pi G T_{\mu 
u}$

Find the unique combination of $R_{\mu 
u}$ and $g_{\mu 
u} R$ which, up to an overall constant, satisfies these conditions.
2013.b.Solution:
$T_{\mu \nu}$, which gives the distribution of mass in a finite volume, is a symmetrical tensor. Hence $K_{\mu \nu}$ must also be a symmetric tensor. As the mass is conserved, $T_{\mu \nu}$ satisfies the equation $T_{\nu ; \mu}^{\mu}=0$. It follows that $K_{\nu ; \mu}^{\mu}=0$.

The Riemann curvature tensor satisfies the Bianchi identity

$$
R_{\mu \nu \kappa ; \gamma}^{\lambda}+R_{\mu \kappa \gamma ; \nu}^{\lambda}+R_{\mu \gamma \nu ; \kappa}^{\lambda}=0 \text {. }
$$

Lowering the index $\lambda$ gives

$$
R_{\lambda \mu \nu \kappa ; \gamma}+R_{\lambda \mu \kappa \gamma ; \nu}+R_{\lambda \mu \gamma \nu ; \kappa}=0,
$$

or, by the skew-symmetry of the Riemann tensor,

$$
R_{\lambda \mu \nu \kappa ; \gamma}-R_{\lambda \mu \gamma \kappa ; \nu}-R_{\mu \lambda \gamma \nu ; \kappa}=0 .
$$

Multiplying through by $g^{\lambda \kappa} g^{\mu \nu}$ and summing, we have

$$
g^{\mu \nu} R_{\mu \nu \kappa ; \gamma}^{\kappa}-g^{\mu \nu} R_{\mu \gamma \kappa ; \nu}^{\kappa}-g^{\lambda \kappa} R_{\lambda \gamma \nu ; \kappa}^{\nu}=0,
$$

or

$$
g^{\mu \nu} R_{\mu \nu ; \gamma}-g^{\mu \nu} R_{\mu \gamma ; \nu}-g^{\lambda \kappa} R_{\lambda \gamma ; \kappa}=0 \text {, }
$$

and finally, as $R \equiv g^{\mu \nu} R_{\mu \nu}$,

$$
R_{; \gamma}-R_{\gamma ; \nu}^{\nu}-R_{\gamma ; \kappa}^{\kappa}=0,
$$

i.e.,

$$
R_{; \gamma}-2 R_{\gamma ; \kappa}^{\kappa}=0,
$$

or

$$
\left(R_{\nu}^{\mu}-\frac{1}{2} \delta_{\nu}^{\mu} R\right)_{; \mu}=0 .
$$

The left-hand side has the form $K_{\nu ; \mu}^{\mu}$. Hence

$$
K_{\nu}^{\mu}=\alpha\left(R_{\nu}^{\mu}-\frac{1}{2} \delta_{\nu}^{\mu} R\right)
$$

where $\alpha$ is a scalar constant. The covariant component is

$$
\begin{aligned}
K_{\mu \nu} &=\alpha g_{\mu \lambda}\left(R_{\nu}^{\lambda}-\frac{1}{2} \delta_{\nu}^{\lambda} R\right) \\
&=\alpha\left(R_{\mu \nu}-\frac{1}{2} g_{\mu \nu} R\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that as

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{\mu \nu} &=R_{\mu \nu \kappa}^{\kappa}=g^{\lambda \kappa} R_{\lambda \mu \nu \kappa}=g^{\lambda \kappa} R_{\mu \lambda \kappa \nu} \\
&=g^{\lambda \kappa} R_{\kappa \nu \mu \lambda}=R_{\nu \mu \lambda}^{\lambda}=R_{\nu \mu},
\end{aligned}
$$

$K_{\mu \nu}$ has the required symmetry.

Lowering the index $\lambda$ gives

or, by the skew-symmetry of the Riemann tensor,

Multiplying through by $g^{\lambda \kappa} g^{\mu \nu}$ and summing, we have

g^{\mu \nu} R_{\mu \nu \kappa ; \gamma}^{\kappa}-g^{\mu \nu} R_{\mu \gamma \kappa ; \nu}^{\kappa}-g^{\lambda \kappa} R_{\lambda \gamma \nu ; \kappa}^{\nu}=0,

$$

The left-hand side has the form $K_{\nu ; \mu}^{\mu}$. Hence

$$
K_{\nu}^{\mu}=\alpha\left(R_{\nu}^{\mu}-\frac{1}{2} \delta_{\nu}^{\mu} R\right)
$$

where $\alpha$ is a scalar constant. The covariant component is

$$
\begin{aligned}
K_{\mu \nu} &=\alpha g_{\mu \lambda}\left(R_{\nu}^{\lambda}-\frac{1}{2} \delta_{\nu}^{\lambda} R\right) \\
&=\alpha\left(R_{\mu \nu}-\frac{1}{2} g_{\mu \nu} R\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that as

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{\mu \nu} &=R_{\mu \nu \kappa}^{\kappa}=g^{\lambda \kappa} R_{\lambda \mu \nu \kappa}=g^{\lambda \kappa} R_{\mu \lambda \kappa \nu} \\
&=g^{\lambda \kappa} R_{\kappa \nu \mu \lambda}=R_{\nu \mu \lambda}^{\lambda}=R_{\nu \mu},
\end{aligned}
$$

$K_{\mu \nu}$ has the required symmetry.In a weak gravitational field the space is essentially Euclidean and the metric tensor has components

$$
g_{\mu \nu}=\eta_{\mu \nu}+h_{\mu \nu}
$$

with $g_{\mu \nu}=0$ for $\mu \neq \nu, \eta_{\mu \nu}=\delta_{\mu \nu},\left|h_{\mu \nu}\right| \ll 1$, except

$$
g_{00}=-\left(1+\frac{2 \Phi}{c^{2}}\right),
$$

where $\Phi$ is the Newtonian scalar potential.

The mass tensor given by

$$
T_{\mu \nu}=\rho c^{2} u_{\mu} u_{\nu},
$$

where $\rho$ is the mass density and $u_{\alpha}$ its four-velocity. If the mass distribution is static,

$$
u_{1}=u_{2}=u_{3}=0, \quad u_{0}=-1 .
$$

Thus all $T_{\mu \nu}=0$ except $T_{00}=\rho c^{2}$.

The Ricci tensor $R_{\mu \nu}$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{\mu \nu} &=g^{\lambda \kappa} R_{\lambda \mu \nu \kappa} \\
&=g^{\lambda \lambda} R_{\lambda \mu \nu \lambda} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} g^{\lambda \lambda}\left(\frac{\partial^{2} g_{\lambda \lambda}}{\partial x^{\mu} \partial x^{\nu}}-\frac{\partial^{2} g_{\mu \lambda}}{\partial x^{\lambda} \partial x^{\nu}}-\frac{\partial^{2} g_{\lambda \nu}}{\partial x^{\mu} \partial x^{\lambda}}+\frac{\partial^{2} g_{\mu \nu}}{\partial x^{\lambda} \partial x^{\lambda}}\right) \\
& \approx \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial^{2} h_{\lambda \lambda}}{\partial x^{\mu} \partial x^{\nu}}-\frac{\partial^{2} h_{\mu \lambda}}{\partial x^{\lambda} \partial x^{\nu}}-\frac{\partial^{2} h_{\lambda \nu}}{\partial x^{\mu} \partial x^{\lambda}}+\frac{\partial^{2} h_{\mu \nu}}{\partial x^{\lambda} \partial x^{\lambda}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In particular, as $h_{\mu \nu}$ do not depend on $x^{0}$ for a static field, we have

$$
R_{00}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\partial^{2} h_{\mu \nu}}{\partial x^{\lambda} \partial x^{\lambda}}=\frac{1}{2} \nabla^{2} h_{00}=\frac{1}{c^{2}} \nabla^{2} \Phi .
$$

In Einstein's equation

$$
R_{\mu \nu}-\frac{1}{2} g_{\mu \nu} R=\frac{8 \pi G}{\alpha} T_{\mu \nu}
$$

raising the index $\mu$ results in

$$
R_{\nu}^{\mu}-\frac{1}{2} \delta_{\nu}^{\mu} R=\frac{8 \pi G}{\alpha} T_{\nu}^{\mu} .
$$

Contraction of $\mu, \nu$ then gives

$$
R-2 R=\frac{8 \pi G}{\alpha} T .
$$

Thus Einstein's equation can be written as

$$
R_{\mu \nu}=\frac{8 \pi G}{\alpha}\left(T_{\mu \nu}-\frac{1}{2} g_{\mu \nu} T\right) .
$$

In particular, we have

$$
R_{00}=\frac{4 \pi G}{\alpha} T_{00}
$$

as $T=g^{\alpha \beta} T_{\alpha \beta}=g^{00} T_{00} \approx-T_{00}$, or

$$
\nabla^{2} \Phi=\frac{4 \pi G \rho c^{4}}{\alpha} .
$$

A comparison with Newton's equation

$$
\nabla^{2} \Phi=4 \pi G \rho
$$

gives

$$
\alpha=c^{4} .
$$

2015.Problem Statement:
The Solar System is accurately described by the Schwarzschild metric

$$
d \tau^{2}=-\left(1-\frac{2 G M}{r c^{2}}\right) c^{2} d t^{2}+\frac{1}{1-\frac{2 G M}{r c^{2}}} d r^{2}+r^{2}\left(d \theta^{2}+\sin ^{2} \theta d \varphi^{2}\right),
$$

where $M$ is the mass of the Sun, $t$ the time coordinate, $r$ the radial coordinate, and $\theta$ and $\varphi$ are polar angles.

A radio pulse is sent from the Earth, reflected off a satellite of Jupiter (the satellite is a point), and received on Earth. Jupiter is a distance $r_{2}$ from the Sun, the Earth a distance $r_{1}$. Assume that Jupiter is on the other side of the Sun relative to us. Let $r_{0}$ be the distance of closest approach of the radio pulse to the Sun. Calculate the gravitational delay in the round-trip time of the radio pulse as a function of $r_{0}$, to the lowest order in $G$. Estimate very roughly the magnitude of the effect, given that 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { mass of the Sun } & \approx 2 \times 10^{33} \mathrm{gm}, \\
\text { radius of the Sun } & \approx 7 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{~cm}, \\
\text { Sun-Earth distance } & \approx 1.5 \times 10^{13} \mathrm{~cm}, \\
\text { Sun-Jupiter distance } & \approx 8 \times 10^{13} \mathrm{~cm}, \\
G & \approx 6.67 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~cm}^{3} / \mathrm{gm} \mathrm{sec}{ }^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$
2015.Solution:
Let

$$
x^{0}=t, \quad x^{1}=r, \quad x^{2}=\theta, \quad x^{3}=\varphi .
$$

Then

$$
\begin{gathered}
g_{00}=-c^{2}\left(1-\frac{k}{r}\right), \quad g_{11}=\left(1-\frac{k}{r}\right)^{-1}, \quad g_{22}=r^{2} \\
g_{33}=r^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta, \quad g_{\mu \nu}=0 \text { for } \mu \neq \nu,
\end{gathered}
$$

where $k=\frac{2 G M}{c^{2}}$. For convenience choose coordinates such that the Earth (E), Sun (S) and Jupiter $(\mathrm{J})$ are in the $\theta=\frac{\pi}{2}$ plane. The equations of the geodesic along which the radio pulse propagates,

$$
\frac{d}{d s}\left(g_{\mu \nu} \frac{d x^{\nu}}{d s}\right)=\frac{1}{2} g_{\alpha \beta, \mu} \frac{d x^{\alpha}}{d s} \frac{d x^{\beta}}{d s},
$$

where $s$ is some orbital parameter, give two first integrals,

$$
\begin{gathered}
g_{3 \nu} \frac{d x^{\nu}}{d s}=g_{33} \frac{d x^{3}}{d s}=r^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta \frac{d \varphi}{d s}=r^{2} \frac{d \varphi}{d s}=\text { constant }, \\
g_{0 \nu} \frac{d x^{\nu}}{d s}=g_{00} \frac{d x^{0}}{d s}=-c^{2}\left(1-\frac{k}{r}\right) \frac{d t}{d s}=\text { constant },
\end{gathered}
$$

since

$$
g_{\alpha \beta, 3}=\frac{\partial g_{\alpha \beta}}{\partial \varphi}=0, \quad g_{\alpha \beta, 0}=\frac{\partial g_{\alpha \beta}}{\partial t}=0 .
$$

Taking ratio of the integrals gives

$$
\frac{r^{2}}{1-\frac{k}{r}} \frac{d \varphi}{d t}=F, \quad \text { a constant. }
$$

For radio waves, $d s^{2}=0$ and the Schwarzschild metric reduces to

$$
\left(1-\frac{k}{r}\right)-\frac{1}{c^{2}}\left[\left(1-\frac{k}{r}\right)^{-1}\left(\frac{d r}{d t}\right)^{2}+\frac{F^{2}}{r^{2}}\left(1-\frac{k}{r}\right)^{2}\right]=0 \text {. }
$$

Fig. $2.5$

The relative positions of $\mathrm{E}, \mathrm{S}, \mathrm{J}$, are shown in Fig. 2.5, where $r_{0} \ll r_{1}, r_{2}$. At $r_{0}$, the closest approach of the radio pulse to the Sun, $\frac{d r}{d t}=0$ and the last equation above gives

$$
F=c r_{0}\left(1-\frac{k}{r_{0}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}} .
$$

Then the coordinate speed of the pulse, $c^{\prime}$, is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
c^{\prime 2} &=\left(\frac{d r}{d t}\right)^{2}+r^{2}\left(\frac{d \varphi}{d t}\right)^{2} \\
&=\left(1-\frac{k}{r}\right)^{2} c^{2}+k r\left(\frac{d \varphi}{d t}\right)^{2} \\
&=\left(1-\frac{k}{r}\right)^{2} c^{2}\left[1+\left(\frac{r_{0}}{r}\right)^{2}\left(1-\frac{k}{r_{0}}\right)^{-1} \frac{k}{r}\right],
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
c^{\prime} \approx\left(1-\frac{k}{r}\right) c,
$$

to first order in $\frac{k}{r}$ and $\frac{r_{0}}{r}$. The time taken for one round trip of the pulse if the Sun did not exert any effect on the speed of light is

$$
T_{0}=\frac{2}{c}\left(\sqrt{r_{1}^{2}-r_{0}^{2}}+\sqrt{r_{2}^{2}-r_{0}^{2}}\right) \text {, }
$$

while the actual time is

$$
T=2 \int_{0}^{\sqrt{r_{1}^{2}-r_{0}^{2}}} \frac{d \xi}{c^{\prime}}+2 \int_{0}^{\sqrt{r_{2}^{2}-r_{0}^{2}}} \frac{d \xi}{c^{\prime}},
$$

where $\xi=\sqrt{r^{2}-r_{0}^{2}}$. As $d \xi=\frac{r d r}{\xi}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
T \approx & \frac{2}{c}\left[\int_{r_{0}}^{r_{1}}\left(1+\frac{k}{r}\right) \frac{r d r}{\sqrt{r^{2}-r_{0}^{2}}}+\int_{r_{1}}^{r_{2}}\left(1+\frac{k}{r}\right) \frac{r d r}{\sqrt{r^{2}-r_{0}^{2}}}\right] \\
=& \frac{2}{c}\left[\sqrt{r_{1}^{2}-r_{0}^{2}}+\sqrt{r_{2}^{2}-r_{0}^{2}}+k \ln \left(\frac{r_{1}+\sqrt{r_{1}^{2}-r_{0}^{2}}}{r_{0}}\right)\right.\\
&\left.+k \ln \left(\frac{r_{2}+\sqrt{r_{2}^{2}-r_{0}^{2}}}{r_{0}}\right)\right] \\
\approx & \frac{2}{c}\left[\sqrt{r_{1}^{2}-r_{0}^{2}}+\sqrt{r_{2}^{2}-r_{0}^{2}}+k \ln \left(\frac{4 r_{1} r_{2}}{r_{0}^{2}}\right)\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the delay time is

$$
\Delta T=T-T_{0} \approx \frac{4 G M}{c^{3}} \ln \left(\frac{4 r_{1} r_{2}}{r_{0}^{2}}\right) .
$$

Taking $r_{0} \simeq$ the Sun's radius and using the given data we find

$$
\Delta T=2.7 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~s} .
$$

2016.c.Problem Statement:
A conformal transformation of a space-time is one where the metric $g_{a b}$ of an original space-time is transformed into the metric $\tilde{g}_{a b}$ of a new space-time such that $\tilde{g}_{a b}$ is related to $g_{a b}$ by

$$
\tilde{g}_{a b}=\Omega^{2} g_{a b},
$$

where $\Omega$ is a function of the space-time coordinates $x^{a}$.
By constructing solutions to Maxwell's equations in Minkowski space, find a formula for the cosmological red shift of light emitted by a galaxy at $t=t_{1}$, and seen by observer at $t=t_{2}$. Assume both source and observer are at rest with respect to the co-moving time coordinate $t$.
2016.c.Solution:
As $\tilde{g}_{a b}=\Omega^{2} g_{a b}$, we have $\tilde{g}^{a b}=\Omega^{-2} g^{a b}$ and $\tilde{g}=-\operatorname{det}\left(\tilde{g}_{a b}\right)=$ $-\operatorname{det}\left(\Omega^{2} g_{a b}\right)=-\Omega^{8} \operatorname{det}\left(g_{a b}\right)=\Omega^{8} g$. Also, for an antisymmetric tensor $T^{\alpha \beta}$ we have

$$
\nabla_{\alpha} T^{\alpha \beta}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{g}} \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{\alpha}}\left(\sqrt{g} T^{\alpha \beta}\right) .
$$

Then in the new space-time we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tilde{\nabla}_{a} F^{a b} &=\tilde{\nabla}_{a}\left(\tilde{g}^{a l} \tilde{g}^{b m} F_{l m}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\tilde{g}}} \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{a}}\left(\sqrt{\tilde{g}} \Omega^{-4} g^{a l} g^{b m} F_{l m}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\tilde{g}}} \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{a}}\left(\sqrt{g} F^{a b}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{\Omega^{4}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{g}} \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{a}}\left(\sqrt{g} F^{a b}\right)=\frac{1}{\Omega^{4}} \nabla_{a} F^{a b}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

and 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tilde{\nabla}_{[a} F_{b c]} &=\frac{\partial F_{b c}}{\partial x^{a}}+\frac{\partial F_{c a}}{\partial x^{b}}+\frac{\partial F_{a b}}{\partial x^{c}} \\
&=\nabla_{[a} F_{b c]} \\
&=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, $F_{a b}$ is also a solution to the source-free Maxwell's equation in the new space-time.

Rewriting the metric of the Robertson-Walker space-time as

$$
\begin{aligned}
d s^{2} &=\left(\frac{t}{t_{0}}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}\left[-c^{2}\left(\frac{t_{0}}{t}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}} d t^{2}+d x^{2}+d y^{2}+d z^{2}\right] \\
&=a^{2}(t)\left[-d \tau^{2}+d x^{2}+d y^{2}+d z^{2}\right] \\
&=\eta_{\mu \nu} d x^{\mu} d x^{\nu},
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
a(t)=\left(\frac{t}{t_{0}}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}, \quad a d \tau=c d t
$$

we see that the metric becomes Minkowskian if

$$
g_{\mu \nu}=\Omega^{2} \eta_{\mu \nu}
$$

with $\Omega^{2}=a^{2}(t)$. As

$$
\tau=c \int \frac{d t}{a(t)}=c \int\left(\frac{t_{0}}{t}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}} d t=\frac{3 c}{2} t_{0}^{\frac{1}{3}} t^{\frac{2}{3}}
$$

putting any constant of integration to zero by resetting the time origins, we have

$$
\Omega^{2}=\left(\frac{t}{t_{0}}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}=\frac{2 \tau}{3 c t_{0}} .
$$

Hence the Robertson-Walker space-time, whose metric tensor is $g_{\mu \nu}$, is conformal to the Minkowski space-time, whose metric tensor is $\eta_{\mu \nu}$, the transformation being

$$
g_{\mu \nu}=\frac{2 \tau}{3 c t_{0}} \eta_{\mu \nu} .
$$

For light, $d s=0$ and thus

$$
a^{2}\left(d \tau^{2}-d r^{2}\right)=0,
$$

where $d r^{2}=d x^{2}+d y^{2}+d z^{2}$, or

$$
d r=d \tau,
$$

i.e.,

$$
r=\tau+\text { constant. }
$$

Take the origin at the light source and consider an observer at position $r$, both being at rest with respect to the co-moving frame of time $t$. The time interval between two consecutive waves is

$$
d t_{1}=\frac{a\left(t_{1}\right)}{c} d \tau
$$

at the source and

$$
d t_{2}=\frac{a\left(t_{2}\right)}{c} d \tau
$$

at the observer. Hence

$$
\frac{\lambda_{2}}{\lambda_{1}}=\frac{c d t_{2}}{c d t_{1}}=\frac{a\left(t_{2}\right)}{a\left(t_{1}\right)}=\left(\frac{t_{2}}{t_{1}}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}},
$$

and the red shift is

$$
z=\frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda}=\frac{\lambda_{2}-\lambda_{1}}{\lambda_{1}}=\left(\frac{t_{2}}{t_{1}}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}-1 .
$$
2016.c.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

2018.b.Problem Statement:
The metric outside a black hole is given by

$$
d s^{2}=-\left(1-\frac{2 m}{r}\right) d t^{2}+\left(1-\frac{2 m}{r}\right)^{-1} d r^{2}+r^{2}\left(d \theta^{2}+\sin ^{2} \theta d \varphi^{2}\right)
$$

where $\theta, \varphi$ are spherical polar coordinates, $r$ is a radial coordinate and $t$ is a time coordinate.

Find the circular orbit for photons in this plane. Is this orbit stable to small perturbations?

The Christoffel symbol is given by

$$
\Gamma_{b c}^{a}=\frac{1}{2} g^{a d}\left(\partial_{b} g_{d c}-\partial_{d} g_{c b}+\partial_{c} g_{b d}\right)
$$
2018.b.Solution:
Letting $x^{0}=t, x^{1}=r, x^{2}=\theta, x^{3}=\varphi$, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
g_{00}=-\left(1-\frac{2 m}{r}\right), \quad g_{11}=\left(1-\frac{2 m}{r}\right)^{-1}, \quad g_{22}=r^{2} \\
g_{33}=r^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta, \quad g_{\mu \nu}=0 \quad \text { for } \mu \neq \nu .
\end{gathered}
$$

The motion of the particle is confined to the plane $\theta=\frac{\pi}{2}$, so $\sin \theta=1$, $d \theta=0$. As $g_{\mu \nu}$ do not depend on $\varphi$ and $t$ explicitly, the geodesic equations

$$
\frac{d}{d s}\left(g_{\mu \nu} \frac{d x^{\nu}}{d s}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\partial g_{\alpha \beta}}{\partial x^{\mu}} \frac{d x^{\alpha}}{d s} \frac{d x^{\beta}}{d s}
$$

yield two first integrals:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{d}{d s}\left(g_{33} \frac{d x^{3}}{d s}\right)=0, \quad \text { or } \quad r^{2} \frac{d \varphi}{d s}=h, \text { a constant, } \\
\frac{d}{d s}\left(g_{00} \frac{d x^{0}}{d s}\right)=0, \quad \text { or } \quad\left(1-\frac{2 m}{r}\right) \frac{d t}{d s}=l, \text { a constant. }
\end{gathered}
$$

As the particle is massless, it moves with the velocity of light and its path is a null geodesic given by

$$
g_{\mu \nu} \frac{d x^{\mu}}{d s} \frac{d x^{\nu}}{d s}=0,
$$

i.e.,

$$
l^{2}-\left(\frac{d r}{d s}\right)^{2}-\frac{h^{2}}{r^{2}}\left(1-\frac{2 m}{r}\right)=0 .
$$

Here $s$ is to be considered an arbitrary independent variable. Let $u=\frac{m}{r}$. Then

$$
\frac{d r}{d s}=-\frac{m}{u^{2}} \frac{d u}{d s}
$$

and the above becomes

$$
l^{2}-\frac{m^{2}}{u^{4}}\left(\frac{d u}{d s}\right)^{2}-\frac{h^{2} u^{2}}{m^{2}}(1-2 u)=0
$$

or

$$
l^{2}-\frac{h^{2}}{m^{2}}\left(\frac{d u}{d \varphi}\right)^{2}-\frac{h^{2} u^{2}}{m^{2}}(1-2 u)=0
$$

as

$$
\frac{d u}{d s}=\frac{d u}{d \varphi} \frac{d \varphi}{d s}=\frac{h u^{2}}{m^{2}} \frac{d u}{d \varphi} .
$$

Differentiating with respect to $\varphi$ gives

$$
\frac{d^{2} u}{d \varphi^{2}}+u=3 u^{2} .
$$

For the circular orbit, $u=$ constant and the orbit equation gives

$$
u_{0}=\frac{1}{3}, \quad \text { or } \quad r_{0}=3 m .
$$

For small perturbations on this orbit, let $u=u_{0}+u^{\prime}$, where $u^{\prime} \ll u_{0}$, and the orbit equation gives

$$
\frac{d^{2} u^{\prime}}{d \varphi^{2}}+u_{0}+u^{\prime} \approx 3 u_{0}^{3}+6 u_{0} u^{\prime}
$$

or

$$
\frac{d^{2} u^{\prime}}{d \varphi^{2}}-u^{\prime}=0,
$$

This has the general solution

$$
u^{\prime}=A e^{\varphi}+B e^{-\varphi},
$$

$A, B$ being constants. As $u^{\prime}$ is not oscillatory the orbit is unstable to small perturbations.
2018.b.Book: Problems and Solutions on Solid State Physics, Relativity and Miscellaneous Topics

2019.b.Problem Statement:
Suppose two compact stars, each of one solar mass, are in a circular orbit around each other with a radius of one solar radius. What is the approximate rate of energy loss due to gravitational radiation from this system? What is the time scale for decay of this orbit? Take

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { solar mass } &=2 \times 10^{33} \mathrm{gm}, \\
\text { solar radius } &=7 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{~cm}, \\
G &=6.7 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \mathrm{gm}^{-1} \mathrm{sec}^{-2}, \\
c &=3 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{~cm} \mathrm{sec}^{-1} .
\end{aligned}
$$
2019.b.Solution:
The total mass-energy of an isolated system is conserved, so it is not possible to radiate monopole gravitational radiation. Also as the total momentum of an isolated system is conserved, which means that the second time derivative of the mass dipole moment $\sum m r$ is zero, it is not possible to radiate dipole gravitational radiation. The lowest multipole gravitational radiation is quadrupole.
For a system of two stars in a circular orbit around their common center of mass, the rate of energy loss by radiation of gravitational waves is

$$
-\frac{d E}{d t}=\frac{32 G^{4}}{5 c^{5} r^{5}}\left(m_{1} m_{2}\right)^{2}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)
$$

where $r$ is their mutual distance, which is constant for motion in a circular orbit. With $m_{1}=m_{2}=m$ and the data given we have

$$
-\frac{d E}{d t}=\frac{64 G^{4}}{5 c^{5} r^{5}} m^{5}=1.57 \times 10^{31} \mathrm{erg} \mathrm{s}^{-1} .
$$

With

$$
\begin{gathered}
E=-\frac{G m^{2}}{2 r}, \\
\frac{d r}{d t}=\frac{2 r^{2}}{G m^{2}} \frac{d E}{d t}=-\frac{128 G m^{3}}{5 c^{5} r^{3}} .
\end{gathered}
$$

As $\frac{d r}{d t}$ is the rate at which the two stars approach each other, the time taken for the complete collapse of the orbit is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tau=\int_{r}^{0} \frac{d r}{\left(\frac{d r}{d t}\right)} &=-\frac{5 c^{5}}{128 G^{3} m^{3}} \int_{r}^{0} r^{3} d r \\
&=\frac{5 c^{5}}{512 G^{3} m^{3}} r^{4}=2.4 \times 10^{15} \mathrm{~s} .
\end{aligned}
$$

In the weak field approximation $g_{\mu 
u}=\eta_{\mu

u}$, Einstein's vacuum equations can be written in the linearized form

\square h_{\mu
